PETITION.TITLE: Jarosite Dumping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to (a) reverse the decision to extend the time allowed Pasminco EZ to dump jarosite at sea, and (b) endorse and comply with the December 1995 deadline established by the London Dumping Convention.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:
1. The majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2. The implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3. We regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully submit that:
The High Court's Mabo decision has caused division and dissension, uncertainty, resentment and economic damage in Australia.
Mabo will not solve the social, educational, housing and other problems of Aboriginal people.
Mabo is an attack on our Federal system of government, under which the absolute control of Crown lands and management of land titles have always rested with the States.

The only solution to Mabo is a referendum of the Australian people for a law to overrule the High Court and re-establish equal land rights for all Australians, under the normal procedures of State and Territory laws.
And we strongly urge the Senate to reject any other proposed solution.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child-care Accreditation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that the Government's proposed scheme for the accreditation of child care centres as set out in the "Quality Improvement and Accreditation System Handbook" be rejected because it:
1.Fails to recognise that Christian values are important to children.
2.Forces parents to relinquish their decision making rights in relation to the manner in which they choose to raise their children.
3.Will cost the taxpayer $11 million dollars to implement without creating a single extra child care place.
4.Forces children and parents to accept values that may be unacceptable to them.
AND your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's oldest and most successful democracies and has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PETITION.PARA: Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when the time allowed for this debate ran out I was speaking in response to the motion by Senator Ferguson to disallow the determination for the salary package—as I suppose it can be put, in common terms—for Mr Kelly to be an adviser to the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I want to put on the record the general description of the job that Mr Kelly would perform as an adviser.

PARA.TAB: At the end of my remarks last night I was explaining that a major part of the Conroy report dealt with the way Customs had introduced new technology. The report said that Customs has been a world leader of any Customs department in doing that, and has been recognised at an international level around the world for chairing committees—in particular, one of the initial committees established by APEC to look at the harmonisation of customs law and rules within our region.

So, despite the criticism in the Conroy review about internal management et cetera, there was strong commendation in that part of the report about Customs for things that it had done at an international level and at a technological level. The government believes that Mr Kelly must take some of the credit for that, because he was a senior officer in Customs as comptroller-general and as deputy of the department before that, and that cannot be ignored. We believe that Mr Kelly is very suitable as special adviser to DITARD on APEC matters.

It should be noted that the APEC ministers in Seattle in November 1993 confirmed to the government the importance to Australia of involvement with the regional groupings through such initiatives as harmonisation of customs procedures, harmonisation of standards and conference procedures, promoting technology transfer between APEC economies and improving market access for Australian manufacturing and service industries within the APEC region. Because of the direct beneficial impact on trade and investment these initiatives will have for Australia, the industry, technology and regional development portfolio—my portfolio—will be substantially increasing its involvement in these areas over the next two to three years.

The role performed by Mr Kelly in maximising the potential gain for Australia in this area has been carefully considered by the department with an interest in APEC matters. His position will involve encouraging interaction of complementary APEC activities within the portfolio and with other departments and agencies; ensuring a commercial orientation of the portfolio's APEC activities that is relevant to business priorities in the region; and representing the portfolio at appropriate APEC meetings. Mr Kelly is well qualified to perform the task of special adviser by virtue of his international experience in customs, particularly in the APEC context where he was involved from the earlier stages in developing a customs theme to encourage trade facilitation through harmonisation.

I believe that the Public Service Commissioner was willing to make the determination that the salary package for Mr Kelly as an adviser for these responsibilities was quite appropriate in view of his experience and, as I said before, the Conroy review not criticising Customs. It commended Customs for what it has done in the area of introducing new technology into its international obligation. In the criticisms being made, I acknowledge the management problems internally and domestically, but I hope that honourable senators, particularly those opposite, will keep some balance in the debate that is taking place.

I said last night that Senator Ferguson's comments in this matter showed a lot of preparation and forethought, and I congratulate him on that. Although I do not agree with the thrust of his remarks, at least they show he has put a lot of effort into this issue compared with some of the hot air windbagging and grandstanding of some other honourable senators opposite.

Senator Ferguson raised the question of how we remove a statutory office holder if there is, as he claimed, incompetence and so on. There are three ways to remove a statutory office holder. One of the ways is by resignation, which is what happened. As I have said before, I had discussions with Mr Kelly and, in consideration of the Conroy review, he agreed to resign from the position of comptroller-general, which is a statutory position. Another way to remove an office holder is by a joint resolution of the houses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I explained all that yesterday.

—Yes, Senator Ferguson explained that. It would be a very inflammatory debate. How long would it take to get that through both houses? It would be a debate centred on a particular individual, and I am not sure that in the end it would be—
—That is not the issue.

—Senator Ferguson raised the ways, if Mr Kelly deserved to go, other than through resignation. Achieving it through the resolution of both houses, I would have thought, in the end might not have brought great credit to the Senate or to the House of Representatives. The debate would have been about a personality. There would have been questions of natural justice and how he could defend himself. He would not have been able to participate in the debate. Those issues would have been raised. We may have ended up with a process going on for months before we resolved the issue one way or the other.

PARA.TAB: From the government's view, we wanted to get on with the job of the reform of Customs, not make ourself a hostage to the process of a joint resolution of the parliament. In fact, it might have been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which could have held hearings to at least give Mr Kelly a chance to put his case. Maybe that is what honourable senators opposite would have wanted. Again, we would have had hours of hearings where Mr Kelly would have been attacked and abused on issues that may not have been particularly germane to what we were debating. I think that process, though it is available to the parliament, is deficient in the context of what we were trying to do in getting on with the job of changing Customs.

The other way of removing a statutory office holder, of course, as Senator Ferguson quite rightly mentioned, is to amend the legislation and abolish the position of comptroller-general. He mentioned the case of the amending and restructuring of the Industrial Relations Court some time ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't mention that.

—Someone else mentioned it. If I remember correctly, it took months and months, if not a year, for that legislation to get through the parliament. Again, the government did not want to wait that long—if we wanted to use that process to remove Mr Kelly or any officer—to change the legislation. We all know how long the business list in the Senate is. Again, it may well have been referred to a committee. We have given a commitment, demanded by the opposition, that we will respond quickly and get on with the job of reforming Customs. So we are damned if we do and we are damned if we do not. I am not saying that to have a go at Senator Ferguson; I think he acknowledged that these were the other processes.

PARA.TAB: In the circumstances, with the Conroy review and its criticism available, I think the resignation of Mr Kelly from the position of comptroller-general was the best outcome. We also have acknowledged that he has a good track record in a number of areas. So, after discussions with him, the department and the Public Service Commissioner, we have offered him a role in which he maintains—for about the equivalent of the remaining period of his statutory office-holder's position, about two years—salary and conditions equivalent to those he would have earned as comptroller-general.

When those opposite describe the individual parts of the package, it is as though some parts of it are special for Mr Kelly. The package is what a departmental secretary is entitled to receive—nothing more, nothing less. There are many other secretaries of departments, all of whom receive the same package.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a responsibility loading? Do you think he is entitled to that?

—Senator Ferguson has interjected about Mr Kelly's responsibility for Customs. The fact that he has resigned may be an indication that he has paid some penalty. That may be an interpretation the public wants to put on his resignation. The way he has been attacked in this place in particular over the past four or five weeks has been so consistent and vigorous and damning that his reputation clearly has been affected. That is a penalty he has paid. For a long time to come the way this matter has been raised and debated in this place will stand against his name. There can be no argument that his reputation has suffered from the way he has been individually attacked in this place. No case has been made to single out Mr Kelly in the way that this motion does and in the way that those opposite have done.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ferguson and Senator Watson spoke about this issue because of their involvement in the appropriate committees. The way some other senators opposite jumped on the bandwagon yesterday to speak in the debate indicated the permanent oppositionist mentality of some of those opposite. They realise that in the foreseeable future they will not be in government and they do not have to address issues of government. If they thought they may be in government in the next six months or at the next election, some wiser heads opposite would have said, `Do we want to set a precedent like this which a future opposition against us may have the numbers in the Senate to use to knock over a determination which we think is reasonable and which even the Public Service Commissioner has agreed to?'

This is a warning sign for those opposite. They ought to think at times about what they would do and how they would act in government, not just how to be a permanent opposition. Nobody in the opposition—National Party or Liberal Party—has had any ministerial experience in government. That has certainly been the case since the introduction of PR in the Senate. It is the first time in the history of the Senate that none of those opposite have had ministerial experience and it is showing somewhat in this debate. I am not referring to the speeches made by Senator Ferguson or Senator Watson. But some of the other speeches indicated to me the opposition's mentality. This approach will lead the opposition into a dead end and make it even more likely that the opposition will be rejected by the people in the future.

My final comment about the process relates to where we are at with the Conroy review. I am very pleased—and Senator Ferguson would probably be pleased—to hear that over the last four or five weeks since the review was tabled I have had extensive consultations with Customs staff. My staff and Customs estimate that I have been to a number of meetings in all of the states. I have spoken to a total of around 2,000 members of Customs staff at meetings that have lasted for between an hour and an hour and a half. At those meetings Customs staff had every opportunity to raise individual issues and present individual recommendations to me and to express their view about the report. I have spoken to the union delegates committees in most states and that has been a very useful process.

This process is extremely important, not only because I hear their views but also because it encourages them to see that the process of change in Customs has to be, as much as anything, driven from the bottom up. I am encouraged by the response I have got from the average staff members. Many of them have accepted much of the criticism in the report. Some of them think they have been individually wrongly accused of things they have not done and they will argue that case in their submission. Many of the ordinary staff say that they never had anything to do with the Midford case and that they should not be blamed for it. At the meetings there was clear criticism by the average staff member of middle and upper management of the organisation. But from those meetings and from over 400 individual and group responses—the consultation process—they are overwhelmingly in favour of the general thrust of reform, and that is a very encouraging start.

I am very pleased with that process and I hope that in the next few weeks, subject to the cabinet list and meetings of cabinet, preparation of the budget, and everything else, I can get a submission to cabinet on the major recommendations and I can make some announcements about where we go forward with Customs. I look forward with confidence to that in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I wish to point to the irrelevancy of a remark made by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht). He indicated that what was lacking in this debate was that no-one in the opposition in the Senate had previous ministerial experience. What has that got to do with it? The minister ought to be taking the responsibility.
—I do.

—Senator Schacht is not taking the responsibility. This discussion should not be taking place in this chamber. The minister, as well as everybody in this chamber, knows what happened. Is the minister saying that Mr Kelly resigned voluntarily? Is he saying that Mr Kelly was not urged to resign by the minister? Is Mr Kelly taking the rap for matters for which the minister should take responsibility? This debate should not be taking place in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: Whatever the government decided to do in respect of one public servant should not have been done in the way that it has been done. It used the Public Service determination, which then brought the matter into the parliament. As we all know, the parliament does have the right to disallow those determinations which, under normal circumstances, are there for particular classes of public servants. They are like an industrial award, if you like. As has been pointed out previously in the debate, it would be a most unusual situation for Public Service determinations to deal with a specific question such as this.

Two things concern me here: firstly, the responsibility of the parliament vis-a-vis the executive government; and, secondly, the responsibility of the executive government to manage the Public Service. I acknowledge what Senator Ferguson has said. He has made a very good case, not for what he is proposing but for what should happen in the future. He has obviously done his homework on this matter and he should be congratulated for that, but what concerns me is that, when we are faced with this situation, as we are now, what does the parliament do about it?

It has been said by the minister—and I think pointed out by Senator Ferguson previously—that, if the executive government considers that some action should be taken in respect of a public servant, and in this case a senior public servant, there are a number of remedies. Included in those remedies is resignation, a motion by both houses of parliament, and the amending of the legislation to abolish the position. What were not mentioned were other disciplinary provisions in the Public Service legislation which are available to the government. The government chose not to go down that track.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think they were available in this case—the disciplinary procedures.
—Because of lack of evidence.
—I think that would be for judgment.
—That is an interesting point. Nevertheless, it appears that—
—There is no suggestion of gross impropriety, which is one of the reasons for dismissal.

—No, I am the last one to suggest gross impropriety—and I am not doing so. But obviously the government wanted something done. It seems to me that Mr Kelly was influenced to take the first option—that is, the resignation from the position of comptroller-general. Presumably the government promised Mr Kelly that his talents would be able to be utilised in another area, and that that would not involve substantial loss of remuneration or entitlement. Therefore, we have before us a disallowable instrument. I do not propose to vote for the disallowance of that instrument because I am not sure that it is the parliament's prerogative to deal with the fate of an individual public servant in this particular way.
—Well put.

—The matter should not have been brought to us in the first place in this way. There are other measures that could be and could have been taken, and these were not taken. I am not in a position at the present moment to see my way clear to vote for the motion of disallowance, much as I commend Senator Ferguson and other opposition senators for raising and pursuing the issue. Obviously, what they have done in the Midford Paramount case over a period of time is ensure that there was a full examination and review of that problem and, indeed, of the efficacy of the Customs operations in this country.

PARA.TAB: I believe that these Public Service determinations and the parliament's ability to disallow those Public Service determinations will be diminished if we allow ourselves to be pushed into pursuing individual cases such as this—and allow ourselves to follow what the government is on about. I will not do that. If my view prevailed—which it will not—any action would play into the hands of the government in this case. So be it. I will not, however, vote for a situation which appears, on the face of it, to be an undue interference by the parliament in the executive government's prerogative and responsibility.

The responsibility rests with the minister. I believe that we have other remedies to pursue his handling of this and other matters. It is not that I deny the power of this parliament or this Senate; I want to uphold it and make sure that the currency of our power is not diminished in any sense when the time comes to ensure the proper functioning and responsibility of the executive government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to the words of my colleague Senator Harradine, and I think in his closing remarks he hit at the nub of his concerns. He said that he had some concerns as to whether it is the role of this parliament to unduly interfere in the processes of executive government. It has always been recognised that this parliament, and this chamber in particular, has a responsibility to oversee, scrutinise and sometimes bring into rein the processes of executive government. That is our foremost task. The question in this case is whether the step which is being embarked upon by this motion is an undue interference or whether, in the course of events, it is justified. That is the nub of the debate.

PARA.TAB: Of course, those who are fresh to this debate may not be fully aware of the history of Mr Kelly's involvement as Comptroller-General of Customs. I am sure there are many in this chamber who are not aware of the history of Customs over the last four years, other than with regard to the Midford Paramount case. I speak as a senator who spent three years overseeing the Customs Service when it appeared before Estimates Committee A. There were many manifest defects in the Customs Service. Midford Paramount was but one case in the sorry story of Customs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember Customs Regulation 4A and the problems we had with that in the early 1980s.

—Yes. There have been many problems with Customs, and there have been many problems recently. The most noticeable, as far as I am concerned, are the manifest problems we had with the Coastwatch contract and the inability of Mr Kelly, when he was given good warning of my intention to question him on the Coastwatch contract, to answer even basic questions such as, `What was the financial situation of the contractor? Did the contractor have sufficient staff to meet its contractual obligations? Did Customs ever, in fact, ensure that the contractor had the sufficient staff?'. We could go into that in great detail.

PARA.TAB: We had a report which was very critical of Customs. Mr Kelly appears to have been persuaded—Senator Harradine quite rightly asked, `How was he persuaded?'—to hand in his resignation and he was then appointed as a special adviser on customs matters with the salary level and entitlements of a departmental secretary. That brings this matter to this chamber, because there was a special determination by the Public Service Commissioner to advance Mr Kelly to the level of a departmental secretary when he had previously been at the level of a deputy secretary.

In Mr Kelly's defence, Senator Schacht said that there is absolutely no reason why those of us on this side or anybody in this chamber should overturn that Public Service Commissioner's determination because Mr Kelly has paid a sufficient price. In that statement alone Senator Schacht recognises that some responsibility attaches to Mr Kelly; otherwise he would not say that Mr Kelly has paid a sufficient price. But what a marvellous price it is when one is asked to bear some of the responsibility for the failures of the Customs Service and one then receives a pay rise. If only I could pay a price like that. This is the nub of the problem.

Senator Schacht made many comments. After listening to Senator Schacht last night, I thought the comments of Ralph Waldo Emerson, that men are always conservative after dinner and that radicals rarely have full stomachs, were highly relevant. Before he assumed his position as a minister on the treasury bench, Senator Schacht was the arch radical. He spent three years with me on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, during which time he espoused every possible radical cause, and I do not begrudge him that right. We had many interesting debates.

Now the arch radical has become the arch conservative. Senator Schacht was advancing a very interesting case last night. He said that it would be a dangerous precedent for this determination to be overturned. He said—and I do not think I am unfairly paraphrasing him—`It has never been done before and we shouldn't do it again'. The arch radical has turned into the arch conservative. But Senator Schacht knows full well that the process by which this determination is made is pursuant to a statute, and certain important observations need to be made with respect to that.

The first and foremost is that in previous times in other parliaments the appointment of people to high office was done by an act of parliament. The effect of the legislation, which sets up the office of the Public Service Commissioner, was to ensure that many of those matters were dealt with by a disallowable instrument, such as a determination. But it is surely not the intention of the statute that this parliament should abrogate its responsibility to oversee those matters; in fact, it is quite the contrary.

The fact that this parliament requires the Public Service Commissioner to make a determination, which is a disallowable instrument, is not an abrogation of the power of this parliament; it is a reservation of the power of this parliament. It means that the parliament will give that responsibility to the Public Service Commissioner, but that this parliament reserves the right to say whether it does or does not agree with this or that determination.

It is an extraordinary argument for Senator Schacht to say, `Look, the Public Service Commissioner has made a determination; parliament should butt out'. If the intention of the act was that parliament should have no oversight and no say in these matters, then why would parliament require such determinations to be disallowable instruments? Parliament made that decision because it wished to reserve the right to oversee that process. So the arch radical turned arch conservative falls at the first hurdle because he does not understand the processes which he purports to be defending.

Senator Schacht then made another argument. In an attempt to persuade Senator Harradine to follow his side of the argument, Senator Schacht said that the parliament overturning a determination of the Public Service Commissioner would be like the parliament overturning a decision of a court or the Industrial Relations Tribunal in relation to an award. That is also a very flawed argument. I am sure Senator Harradine will appreciate the fact that the Public Service Commissioner is not a judicial officer, a court or a judge.

That argument is highly flawed. It is like saying that the parliament should not be allowed to oversee any actions of this individual. It is like saying that the actions of the Public Service Commissioner should be sacrosanct. In my role as Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I can assure this Senate that we have been highly active in scrutinising the determinations of the Public Service Commissioner. We have disallowed many determinations of the Public Service Commissioner for a whole range of reasons, yet Senator Schacht, through his argument, seems to be denying us any power at all. His argument is clearly flawed. In upholding the suggestions put forward by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, this Senate recognises the fact that there is a role to oversee the determinations of the Public Service Commissioner. The Public Service Commissioner is not sacrosanct. He is not above review and nor are his decisions.

Senator Schacht then tried to take the argument one step further. He said, `Look, this is a disallowable instrument. The only ground that you have to disallow the determination is if it is improperly made'. He suggested that the Senate had the power to disallow the determination only if there were some defect in the process. That is not true. There is certainly a role for the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to disallow regulations that have a technical defect or where they breach one of the terms of reference to that committee. There is a general power for this Senate at any time, for whatever reason, to disallow a disallowable instrument; and that is a step we are taking. For Senator Schacht to say that there is no power or that the power is limited only to determinations which are improperly made or not made in the course of proper process is an absolute nonsense. So the arguments that Senator Schacht advances in this matter are extremely weak.

In the case made by my colleague Senator Ferguson the question is: is it appropriate in these circumstances, in view of the manifest values of Customs over the past few years in which Mr Kelly has been comptroller-general, for him to be appointed to this position at this particular level of remuneration? The opposition, and other senators in this chamber, have formed the view that it is not. Not one argument has been advanced by the minister to say that what we are doing is improper. In fact, it is highly proper, because it seeks to ensure that parliament properly oversights the actions of executive government.

It is interesting that the arch radical, having become a minister—now the arch conservative—is not so keen on the oversighting of executive government. It is entirely proper that this parliament sets standards and guidelines which should be followed. It is entirely proper, at a time when government is saying that it wants to make the terms and conditions of Public Service remuneration more like the terms and conditions in the private sector because it wants to attract the best talent, that we ensure that there are rewards for success and penalties for failure. That is the basis upon which Senator Ferguson has moved this motion of disallowance.

I support my colleague Senator Ferguson entirely; he is correct. If the minister perhaps had not had so much to eat last night and was not such an arch conservative, and had considered the consequences of what was happening here, he too would recognise the fact that there is inherent merit in the motion which was moved by Senator Ferguson last night and which will be voted upon this morning.

PARA.TAB: For the life of me, I really cannot see how the minister can talk about Mr Kelly being denied justice when compared with what happened to the people involved in Midford Paramount. SPEECH.PARA: Subject to subsection (2), the Board may, by instrument in writing, determine the terms and conditions of employment (including employment overseas) of officers and employees.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the minister has been badly advised on this particular issue, and it does him no credit at all to suggest that a dangerous precedent will be set. The only dangerous precedent that has been set is that the minister has chosen to reward Mr Kelly by paying him a salary package higher than he is legally entitled to. The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill proposes an amendment to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986. Details of the amendment are set out in the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the Bill.

The Bill has been made necessary by the issue of Letters Patent to the Honourable Gordon Samuels AC QC and also to Mr Michael Codd AC to conduct an inquiry into the operation and management of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service. That Inquiry has been asked by the Government to report if possible by 30 September 1994 and in any case by 31 December 1994. As the terms of reference include the effectiveness and suitability of existing arrangements for control and accountability of ASIS and the resolution of grievances and complaints relating to ASIS, it is likely that the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security will have information and documents which would be of considerable relevance to the Inquiry.

Advice from the Attorney-General's Department is that provisions in the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act which were intended to give the maximum possible protection to information held by the Inspector-General may preclude the Inspector-General from providing information or documents to the Inquiry and therefore substantially impede the ability of the Inspector-General to co-operate with the Inquiry. Subsection 34(1) of the Act precludes the Inspector-General and his or her staff from disclosing or communicating to any person any information obtained by the reason of the person having held one of those positions except in the performance of duties and the exercise of powers under the Act. The Inspector-General's powers and functions are listed comprehensively in the Act and do not include the giving of evidence to Royal Commissions and similar inquiries.
The effect of this is that the Inspector-General may not lawfully disclose information or give documents to the Inquiry.

Mr President, the Bill is intended to remove this difficulty. It will permit the current and former Inspector-General and the current and former staff of the Inspector-General to give information and evidence to the Commissions of Inquiry conducted by the Honourable Gordon Samuels and Mr Michael Codd without risking prosecution. In that way, it will ensure that the Commissions have access to a class of information which would be among the most relevant available.

The point should be emphasised that the amendment made by the Bill will not permit the disclosure of information or the giving of documents by the Inspector-General or staff other than to the specified Commissions of Inquiry just referred to. In that way, the present position, which emphasises the need to maintain the greatest possible protection for the privacy of individuals and for information about matters related to security, will be preserved as far as possible.

The introduction of the Bill is a measure of the importance which the Government attaches to enabling the Commissions of Inquiry to conduct the fullest examination of the matters within their Terms of Reference.
I commend the Bill to the Senate

TALK.START.PARA: —You are laughing at yourself.

Eleven years after the government first introduced this matter into the chamber, it has decided that it should be put on the front of the agenda again and that it should now be debated. The register of senators' interests—this crucial part of the government's accountability package—is so urgent it has to be guillotined today. We even have to have a retrospective guillotine on the debate on the time limits on the guillotine. The amendments to the Audit Act will be put off until Christmas and they may still be awaiting debate in 1995; in fact, we may never see them again because they do not seem to be important to the government and the Democrats.

There is no clear commitment that the Auditor-General will have the resources to do proper inquiries. All we are given is a vague reference to the fact that the government will review the Auditor-General's resources in the normal budgetary process. That is nothing new; of course, the Auditor-General's finances and appropriations are reviewed every year.

We are having an inquiry, finally—with no help from the Australian Democrats, I might say—into the Centenary House affair. When this inquiry was originally raised by the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator McMullan, it was going to be a private inquiry that did not even report to the parliament. A firm commitment still has not been given in this place about the inquiry into the Centenary House affair, which I remind honourable senators involves a deal that the Australian Labor Party receive an over-market rent on a 15-year lease with a nine per cent increase every year.

One of the few pieces of paper coming out of the Auditor-General's office that the government reads on a monthly basis is the monthly rent cheque from the Auditor-General's office. The government does not like reading the Auditor-General's reports. It does not like reading the reports into the sports rorts affair. It does not like reading the reports into the abuse of the Australian government credit card. What government members, especially over there at Centenary House in the Labor Party offices, love reading is the rent cheque that comes from the Auditor-General every month.

The government loves receiving it because every year it is a better story—it gets bigger by nine per cent. It is a lovely bit of paper. But unless it is reformed—and reformed urgently, because in September that rent is going up again by nine per cent; we will see that work through the budget process—every time that rent goes up by nine per cent, the resources of the Auditor-General go down by eight per cent. As we talk here today, there is only a one per cent increase in the Auditor-General's property operating expenses. What the Australian Labor Party likes reading from the Australian National Audit Office is the rent cheques; it does not like the reports.

The reason that this matter is important and that the timeliness of these reform measures for the Auditor-General are crucial now is that only yesterday I incorporated in Hansard a letter from the Auditor-General saying that he wants to do an inquiry into the allegations I have raised about uncommercial practices by Dasfleet. Dasfleet is engaged in tax evasion. It has cost the Australian taxpayer in the vicinity of $234,240 in the past 15 months in unpaid sales tax due to an administrative failure within Dasfleet and through a deal which supplies executive cars, like Ford Fairmonts, to the Transport Workers Union and government fuel cards which provide fuel at 59c a litre. These cars are supplied at a discount to the trade union movement of between $250,000 and $500,000 every year. The Auditor-General wants to look into it. In the letter that I incorporated into Hansard yesterday, the audit office said that it would like to conduct a full inquiry into my allegations; however, it is severely constrained by resources.

It is urgent that the Auditor-General's resources be improved and that his independence be assured. But here we are, at the behest of the Australian Democrats, debating as a matter of extreme urgency the registry of senators' interests. This matter should involve a thorough debate on all of the issues. It goes to the heart of accountability in the democratic process and does deserve a debate. We have had a debate before, but, as Senator Harradine quite properly points out, there are new senators and new issues, including those resulting from the piggery affair and the sports rorts affair. Thankfully, the whole accountability issue is at the top of the political agenda again.

This is what the Australian Democrats consider urgent. I wonder whether they consider it urgent for there to be a full inquiry into the potential political corruption of the operations and uncommercial dealings of Dasfleet. As it stands at the moment, the Auditor-General may not have the resources to undertake what is a sensible inquiry, something that the people need to understand. People do not like the Australian Labor Party government delivering benefits to its trade union mates—delivering them Ford Fairmonts and cheap petrol at 59c a litre. They do not like it.

On 3 March the Senate refused to investigate potential political corruption. With the support of the Democrats and Senator Harradine, the Senate—shamefully, I suggest—turned its eyes away from the potential political corruption, the smoking gun in the sports rorts affair. That was a very sad day for the Senate and a very sad day for accountability, because the Auditor-General said that he did not have the resources to go back and try to uncover the audit trail which had been erased from the whiteboard. The Senate had the power and the capacity to go through the grants, talk to the people, investigate the local needs and find out whether there was political corruption. But the Senate said no. Mrs Kelly, as a minister—I think it was John Stone, the former head of Treasury, who described ministers as just part-players who flit across the political stage—just flitted across the political stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —We know whom he was referring to.
—He was not referring to Mrs Kelly. He might not have even envisaged that she would be a minister some day; in fact, he might have been horrified to even contemplate it back in 1982.
—Name whom he was referring to.

—We know to whom he was referring, and it was no-one like Mrs Kelly. In the development of Australian parliamentary democracy, Mrs Kelly has but a cameo role. So her resignation was nothing. It was something to ensure that the Labor government did not have to endure any more political flak than it had already endured, and it was decided to cut her out. She was not the issue. The issue of political bias and political corruption within government programs is the issue that lives with us. There are the accountability packages, including the package that Senator Gareth Evans put down on 3 March. The deal that was effectively cobbled out over a couple of meetings between Mr Beazley and Senator Kernot is part of the solution. But the timeliness of implementing that solution is crucial, and we are debating the time limits in this debate.

PARA.TAB: The point I am making in a roundabout and detailed way is that this accountability package, part of which is the register of senators' interests, includes some important measures. They are measures that should take place anyway, regardless of whether or not there is a Senate inquiry into the sports rorts affair. There should be a Senate inquiry into the sports rorts affair. It is a crucial issue of public accountability. All of the other measures that Senator Evans mentioned on 3 March, including the one we are debating today, are important, but they are ones which should take place anyway. They are not things which should be new initiatives of the government. The Auditor-General should be independent, and of course he should be properly resourced, regardless of the inquiry into the Centenary House affair, which is yet another inquiry into government mismanagement and political corruption. They are things that should be investigated.

There are matters of importance that need to be considered whenever a guillotine is considered, and Senator Harradine of course has referred to those. Whenever senators' times and opportunities to speak are limited, we then impede the whole process of accountability of government. So I will not be supporting the guillotine, and I certainly will not be supporting paragraph (3) of the motion which involves a retrospective guillotine. It says that, for every minute I speak, I limit the time of some senator who in the future may want to contribute to the debate. So, with the nodding approval of my deputy whip, I will sit down and register my abhorrence of this new device called `a retrospective guillotine'.

TALK.START.PARA: —This substantive motion was last debated on 30 August 1993. Senator Panizza was on his feet at that time. I thought that in the ensuing time—quite a few months—he might have spruced up his act a little. But it was sad to see that, even today, Senator Panizza's speech was even more convoluted and confused than it was on that occasion. I thought that bit of extra time for him to think about this issue may have done some good, but I am sad to record that, unfortunately, he, in common with the remainder of the opposition, appears to have gone backwards on this issue.

PARA.TAB: I do not think there is any need for me to repeat what the government put on record about this matter when it was debated in 1987, 1992 and again last year, as I mentioned in the earlier debate, in both the autumn and budget sittings. The key issue before the Senate again today is whether or not a declaration of pecuniary interests is a right and proper thing for Australian parliamentarians to do. That is the key issue. We on this side of the chamber believe it is the right thing; we always have. We have always been committed to that fundamental principle.

The government has said for a long time that the introduction of this system, which was adopted by the House of Representatives in 1986, is very long overdue for senators in this place. We see it as a minimum requirement of responsible, accountable, democratic government that honourable members and senators be required to reveal their pecuniary interests to the electorate—the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —When are you going to do it?

—I have, in fact. It is a very basic safeguard against conflict of interests. On this side of the chamber, we make no claim that the system as proposed is absolutely perfect. Any system that is adopted by any parliament has to attempt to reconcile the right to privacy of all citizens, whether they be members of parliament or not, with the basic right of electorates to information about their elected representatives. This proposed system attempts to strike, and I believe succeeds in striking, that balance.

PARA.TAB: Members of parliament are required to declare the nature of their pecuniary interests but not the precise extent of those interests. They are also required to declare the interests of their spouses and dependent children, but such declarations are to remain confidential unless the proposed committee on senators' interests determines that there is a conflict of interest.

One might legitimately argue that the balance which the proposed system attempts to strike between these competing considerations errs on one side or the other. One cannot legitimately argue, as the opposition has tried to do in the past, that the system violates the right to privacy in requiring senators to declare, albeit confidentially, the pecuniary interests of their spouses and dependent children and, at the same time, panders to the right to privacy in requiring senators to declare their interests only in the broad rather than in precise financial terms.

The opposition has spoken at great length and made much of its support for the general principle of declaration of interests but cannot vote for or support the system that this government has proposed. It has trotted out a litany of alleged shortcomings in the proposed forms that are to be filled in and a litany of alleged inadequacies, suggesting that the definitions are imprecise or people may not be filling out the forms accurately. It is suggesting, of course, that the forms have these sorts of shortcomings—that they are ambiguous, unclear and so forth. This needs to be recognised as nothing more than an excuse by the opposition for doing nothing at all—which is its fundamental position of lack of principle on this issue. It ought to be pointed out to those geniuses on the other side of the chamber who believe that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Name the geniuses.

—I would be struggling, Senator McKiernan. That is a very unfair interjection. I point out to those on the other side of the chamber, who think they can design better forms for the declaration of pecuniary interests and a better system, that we will be providing, as an integral part of the system that we are putting forward, a very effective forum in which they can pursue that matter—the proposed committee of senators' interests, which will be debated after we have dealt with this substantive motion.

PARA.TAB: The responsibilities of this committee will include consideration of any proposals made by senators and others as to the form and the content of the register. The committee will consider any submissions made in relation to the registering or declaring of interests. It will be able to consider what class of persons, if any, other than senators, ought to be required to register and declare their interests. The committee will also be able to make recommendations on those matters and any other matters that are relevant and brought before it in a proper way. So there is a mechanism to deal with this alleged inadequacy of the forms.

The key thing is that if a senator fills out a form such as the one that has been used voluntarily by government senators—as a result of the frustration we have all felt because the opposition is not fair dinkum on this issue, and never has been—that senator can be held accountable for what he or she does or does not declare on the form. That is the principle involved. That is the commitment that this government—in terms of every senator and every member of the House of Representatives—has shown. To be fair, so have the Australian Democrats and, I believe, the Western Australian Greens. I am not sure whether Senator Harradine made such a declaration or not. But other senators, independents and minor party senators in this chamber, have joined the government—out of a sense of frustration because of the desperate attempts by the opposition to stop this matter coming to a conclusion—and showed they were fair dinkum by voluntarily placing before the Australian people a declaration of their interests.

We are not proposing that the system that we are putting forward today ought to be engraved in stone forevermore—that is not our suggestion. It will be open to the opposition, it will be open to all parties represented on the committee, to put forward at any time suggestions to improve the system. I believe that is an appropriate way for the government to act and respond. It also ought to be put on record today that the government has shown flexibility in this matter, as well as a willingness to see it come to its conclusion, but we have demonstrated our flexibility by taking on board and reflecting in motions before the chamber—
