DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: New South Wales Police Service: Taxation of Severance Pay

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to address an issue in relation to which I suppose I should declare a pecuniary interest on behalf of my late spouse. It involved a mistake by the New South Wales Police Service from 1978 to 1989 through which it overtaxed the long service leave component of those members of the force who left as a result of either voluntary retirement at age 60 or 65 or discharge on medical grounds. For those 11 years, the New South Wales Police Service overtaxed these members' long service payment on their retirement. Some of them have been overtaxed by around $1,000 or $1,500—not inconsequential amounts of money.

PARA.TAB: We first became aware of the matter when the Retired Police Association advised its members in 1990-91 that this had taken place and that they should contact the service to ask it to recalculate their severance pays and to calculate by how much they had been overtaxed. According to the police service, my husband has probably been overtaxed by something like $1,000. The Retired Police Association knows of in excess of 200 other members who have been overtaxed.

It also appears from questions that have been asked in the state parliament that the New South Wales Police Service was not the only New South Wales government agency which did this. I am not sure which other New South Wales government agencies in fact did overtax their separating members, but certainly others have been involved. One of my colleagues in the other place spoke on this matter in the adjournment debate on 23 February. I commend that speech to honourable senators.

I became aware of the situation in 1990-91. The problem was very easy to fix for those people who had separated after 1 July 1986 because the three-year period of the statute of limitations for taxation was in force and they were able to seek recalculations and reassessments. The ones having problems are those who separated from the police force—and, obviously, from elsewhere in the New South Wales Public Service and associated organisations—at some time between 1978 and 1986. Those people have to attempt either to get an ex gratia payment from the state government—because it made the mistake—or to come back to the federal Department of Finance and ask it to make repayments for the overtaxing.

This issue has dragged on since early 1991. There are now a number of estates held up because of the recalculations that have to be made and this overtaxing that needs to paid back. I personally do not know of any, but there must be estates that this has affected for something like three or four years. It must be extremely disappointing and traumatic for the families of those members to have this hanging over their heads. To lose one's spouse or a close family member is difficult enough, but to have this situation as a constant reminder of what has happened is intolerable.

A number of questions have been placed on notice in the New South Wales state parliament. On 3 March last year—it is at page 219 of the state Hansard—in answer to a question on notice, the police minister admitted that from August 1978 to July 1989 the New South Wales Police Service incorrectly calculated the tax payable on accumulated long service leave payments to employees on termination of services and that a number of other government departments and instrumentalities were also incorrectly calculating this particular tax.

He further went on to say that the New South Wales service was only one of a number of New South Wales government agencies at the time which misconstrued the taxation affecting termination lump sums. He was sympathetic to the claims by the affected employees of the police service. General issues of compensation for these individuals, and for the affected former members of any other government agency, is something that can be resolved only at government level through state Treasury. That was in March 1993.
We have a further answer to a question on notice on 11 November 1993. I think it is page 2406 from the state Hansard. This one is from the Premier and the Minister of Economic Development:

SPEECH.PARA: The government will be announcing its decision regarding ex-gratia payments when it has considered all the issues relating to the matter.
That is fair enough.

Of chief concern is whether it is possible to obtain compensation from the Commonwealth on behalf of the retired police. The delay is mainly caused by the length of time which has elapsed since the police service incorrectly interpreted and processed taxation on lump sum entitlements of retiring police. The mistake was made so long ago that it is difficult and time consuming to reconstruct events and recalculate the amounts which would be payable. These calculations must be made before a formal approach is made to the Commonwealth. The ministry of police and emergency services is actively investigating the matter and is retrieving records in order to establish who should be compensated and the amounts involved.

That raises a question with me: the 200-odd in the Retired Police Association know they are affected. What I think somebody should be asking the New South Wales government is just how many of their former employees are affected by this, because I think it could be a substantial number, but it may not be.

PARA.TAB: The next question to the New South Wales government is: how is it going to advise these people of their rights, of the fact that they have been overtaxed, and how they should go about endeavouring to retrieve this overtaxed amount of money? To someone who is living on a pension, and be it living on a police pension, $1,000 is a huge amount of money. I will say more about the amounts of the police pension shortly.

I think that is a very important question. The New South Wales government and police department have to ask—because they are the ones with the primary files—just how many of their members have been overtaxed, and how they plan to contact those people.

I now have a copy of a letter that Mr Hocking, the honorary state president of the Retired Police Association of New South Wales Inc. has received from the acting director of human resources of the New South Wales Police Service. This indicates that the service has decided that morally the responsibility for repayment lies with the Commonwealth government, and that the best way of dealing with the issue might be for the state government to formally approach the Commonwealth government for assistance in resolving this matter. The letter further states that the Treasurer is at present considering how this might best be done.

That was in February of this year. Again, state departments that have been involved are not moving particularly quickly. I would only urge them to speed up their work and to be cognisant that there are at least 220 that I personally know of who are affected, and there are a number of estates that are affected. Some of these estates could be of people who have died three or four years ago—or maybe even longer. I would think that if the widows, particularly of those police officers, are entitled to $1,000, they should be receiving $1,000, because the widow's component of the police pension is not particularly great.

That brings me to another issue which I intend to pursue through several paths, and one of which I will be pursuing as a member of the superannuation committee. But I would bring to your notice today also the issue in relation to pensions to the spouses of deceased police officers, and that is, what I consider, the gross anomaly. Whilst it does not affect me financially—I obviously have an occupation where I am, I think, well remunerated—there would be a number of people out there, usually women, who, upon the death of their spouses, would want to know what finances are available to them, and would want those to be fixed up very quickly.

It came to my attention that, to be eligible to obtain the widow's pension from the superannuation fund, one had to be married to the superannuant at the time of his separation from the New South Wales police force. In my case, my husband left the police force on 12 November 1982. We were married on 28 March 1987, so we were married for nearly seven years. I am informed that because we were not living together in a de facto relationship in 1982, or married—in fact, I publicly say we did not know one another then—I am ineligible for the widow's part of the pension.

I do not know whether there are a great number of widows or widowers affected by this, but certainly a number of police officers are discharged for medical reasons from the police force at a reasonably early age. When they are medicalled out, the police force gets its pound of flesh off them first. They do not get medicalled out for trivial reasons; they are medicalled out for very good reasons. A lot of these people, if medicalled out when young, could well have re-married or married for the first time. They might well have been married for up to 10, 20, 30 or 40 years, but because they were not married or in a de facto relationship at the time of separation from the job, they would be ineligible for that part of the police pension that the widows are entitled to.

I found out about this through a phone call I had from the State Superannuation Board. I was told quite abruptly, after I had been led to believe I was entitled to the pension by the police welfare—but police welfare may not have known the key dates so I am not critical of that body—that I was not eligible. I also had to inquire as to what date the superannuation entitlement payments ceased. They ceased from the date of death, so, given that most people would take at least a week for the wheels to turn to advise the superannuation board that an overpayment made has been made, most of the estates would be up for an overpayment. I casually asked this because I was not sure; I had assumed that it might have been like the Department of Social Security where there are a number of payments made at the old rate before they cut out to the single rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are six.

—That is right, there are six payments. But, no, this happens at the date of death. I got a lovely letter saying in the second paragraph that they were sorry my husband had died, but we had been made an overpayment of $297.75. That was not a particularly nice letter. I make the point that all the time this had been happening, people did not know what my professional capacity was. I had been doing this as Mrs Martin, not as Senator West.

PARA.TAB: When I got this letter, I was, to say the least, not impressed. When I asked about it during the phone conversation, the comment was just briskly and brusquely made that I would have to talk to social security if I needed some money. I said that I did not need to talk to social security. It was a particularly horrible attitude. As I say, they had written to me to tell me that an overpayment had been made, and during the telephone conversation I asked for a written determination as to why I was ineligible for the widow's part of the superannuation and they sent me back this letter which did not address that at all. I then wrote to them again and requested a written determination on that—advising them, as they had requested, who the solicitor handling the estate was. I also requested a copy of the trust deeds for the superannuation fund of which my husband was a member.

I received a written determination which was fairly scanty telling me it was in the terms of the `Police Regulations Superannuation Act 1906'. However, I have not received from them either a copy of that act or the trust deeds. This is an issue which I intend to discuss with the ISC because I am not quite sure where it is going to fit within the superannuation scheme of things. I would think that, as I had written as the widow of a superannuant member of the superannuation fund, I would be entitled to a copy of the trust deeds. If there are no trust deeds—and I do not know how that would come about—at least I should be entitled to a copy of the act and regulations which determine how these decisions and determinations are made. I have yet to take that up because this is a rather difficult business.

I bring these things to the attention of honourable senators today and anyone who is listening out there because in difficult times one does not need to be treated like this. The treatment that I received as Mrs Martin was certainly a lot different to the treatment that I would normally have received as Senator West. As to the treatment that Mrs Martin got in a number of departments, whilst some have been absolutely wonderful, there have been others which have certainly been lacking in a lot of respect and understanding of the difficult times that families have to face.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was angered recently when I listened to the attack by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) on the medical profession. I intended replying on their behalf, but I realised that his attack stemmed more from ignorance than from his knowledge. It was simplistic. While I was pondering this, I happened to read the latest news bulletin from the President of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: At the beginning of October I decided that I should make `trust' the topic for my next Newsletter. A few days later, I was privileged to attend the Harveian Dinner of the Royal College of Physicians and to hear Professor Leslie Turnberg speak on this topic after dinner. His words so precisely and concisely expressed my own thoughts that I sought his permission to quote them.
I, in turn, wish to quote Professor Norman Browse, the President of the Royal College of Surgeons of England. He said that the President of the Royal College of Physicians of England said:

PARA.TAB: I want to spend a moment talking about the nature of the relationship between doctor and patient, and the potential threats being posed to that interaction. It is a relationship which is critically dependent on trust, and extremely sensitive when that trust is replaced by suspicion. And there is no denying that there are tensions at the moment which may interrupt or inhibit that trust.

The interaction between doctor and patient, a key element of any health system, has been changing over the last 20 to 30 years. The autonomy of patients has increased as their desire to become much more directly involved in their own care has developed. And acceptance by the patient of the doctor's opinion is less the norm now than it was, and our desire to do the best we can for our patients, acting simply in a benign form of paternalism, is clearly no longer sufficient or appropriate. But preserving the doctor's beneficence at a time when patients want to be involved to a much greater extent in decisions about their care, to choose their treatment, or even exercise their right to refuse treatment, is an adjustment we have to make. But, as we adjust, it is essential that we preserve the trust which contributes so much to the quality of care.
Patients consult doctors at a time of need when their morale is often at a low ebb. They are anxious and even desperate in their need to trust that their doctors will do their best for them.

But there is now a danger that this relationship may be threatened. If patients suspect that their doctors may be weighing up the cost of what should be done for them against what may be done to treat other patients for the greater good of society, then that critical trust is eroded.

We all accept that resources can never keep up with demand and that the gap between what we do now and what we can afford is widening. The dilemma of having to choose how to use limited resources is not new, but the more doctors seem to be part of any process of rationing the less patients will trust them.

There is a clear distinction to be drawn between the absolutely necessary process of setting priorities for health care and that involved in the provision of care by an individual doctor for an individual patient. This dilemma faces the Colleges as well as each doctor but, while we play our part in helping the politicians to tease out the priorities of health care need, neither the Colleges nor individual physicians wish to be seen to be part of a rationing process in which some treatments are denied because of lack of funds; that is something which society has to decide through government and their representatives in management. This poses a particular difficulty for those physicians who take on the dual role of clinician and manager and thus have to participate on behalf of the Health Service in decisions about the distribution of scarce resources. We must ensure that these roles are clearly distinguished and the two modes of behaviour—both important—are not confused. The implications of not doing so are bad for doctors and bad for patients.

The current wave of adverse criticism of members of the medical profession in the press cannot be dissociated from this failing trust which, at least in part, comes from the uncertainty about what role doctors are playing in the Health Service. I do not believe we can ignore what the public and the press is saying.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Browse went on to say:

PARA.TAB: I echo the words and sentiments of the PRCP which epitomise the concern of all the Colleges. As surgeons, we find ourselves in the front-line of the battle for the trust of our patients for, in addition to the problems of rationing and two-tier care, we have to endure television programmes claiming that surgeons perform operations for which they have not been trained, and which they have never performed before. How can we sustain the public's trust? We can and we should, because most of the TV and press statements are untrue or—worse—relate to a minute proportion of our colleagues and because most surgeons are wholly deserving of their patients' trust and support. Nevertheless, trust can only be maintained—or in some instances regained—by our individual dedication to our patients' welfare, by being open and honest, and by providing evidence that we are properly trained, and maintaining our knowledge and expertise by continuing our education throughout our professional life.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that that be on the record because it might explain to the bureaucracy and to Senator Richardson the distinction that must be drawn between the medical profession as a whole and the health economists. The health economists and the bureaucracy are hell-bent on the rationing of resources. On the other hand, the individual medical practitioner has the responsibility to care for the particular patient before him.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson does not appreciate that if his proposals go ahead he will destroy that essential trust that a patient should have in his or her doctor because the doctor then becomes the budget holder for the bureaucracy and government. Senator Richardson obviously does not understand. I tried to point out to him once that what he was proposing would destroy a relationship that had been present for over 2,000 years—when the principles of the Hippocratic oath were enunciated—that the responsibility of the doctor was to the patient and not to the budget provider. I thought it was essential I read this into the record so that if Senator Richardson does not read it, perhaps somebody in his department will.

In Australia, the Royal Australasian College of Surgeons has introduced a system of continuing medical education and is about to introduce time-limited mandatory specialist registration. The Royal Australasian College of Surgeons is in the forefront in this regard. The Australian public can be assured that their trust in Australian surgery and Australian medicine is well placed and will continue to be well placed because the medical profession as a whole through its body, the Australian Medical Association, will be resisting whatever proposals are being presented by government—of whichever persuasion—which will come between that essential trust which must remain between a patient and his or her doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently there were gatherings in the Hunter Valley, in Maitland and in Dungog to pay tribute to the voluntary bushfire brigades, other volunteers and government services that provided such wonderful support during the bushfire problems that scourged New South Wales last January. These people risked their own lives to protect life and property in the areas of Port Stephens, Maitland, Cessnock, Singleton and Dungog in the Hunter Valley.

PARA.TAB: I want to place on record our congratulations, particularly on the work of the Hon. Terry Griffiths, the Minister for Police and Emergency Services, and Commissioner Phil Koperberg, who directed the central bushfire fighting efforts. It was their leadership that helped stop a disaster from turning into an absolute catastrophe for the people of New South Wales.

As soon as I returned to the Senate, I presented a notice of motion thanking those people for their support. I would like to repeat that notice of motion because at the end of it I want to point out something about the Labor Party's attitude. I gave notice that I would move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a) expresses its dismay at the devastation caused earlier in January 1994 by the horrifying bushfires in New South Wales;
(b) extends condolences to the families and friends of the four people who tragically died as a result of the fires;
(c) offers its sympathy to the many people who lost all their possessions as a result of the bushfires;

(d) sends the highest praise and commendation to the thousands of professional and volunteer bushfire fighters who risked life and limb in a valiant and courageous effort to contain the fires and prevent even more devastating loss of life and property;
(e) congratulates the many Australians who have pulled together and so generously given money and goods to the various appeals for assistance to the victims of the fires; and—

SPEECH.PARA: this final point is the one that I want to comment on—

PARA.TAB: (f) commends the NSW Coalition Government for developing and implementing a strategic plan which helped to minimise the impact of this disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: Having given that notice of motion, it was suggested that we should declare it formal and then bring it on later for further debate. However, when this matter was put to the ALP, it said that it would be happy to do that, provided that item (f) was dropped off the motion. Item (f) commends the New South Wales government for its firefighting effort. How petty and mean-minded! I was not prepared to do that. I wanted that commendation to stand on the Senate record, and so I repeat it today. It was only because of the way in which the New South Wales government prepared for this, the structures that it had set up, the strength of its personnel and the excellence of its leadership that a greater disaster was averted. This should be on the public record.

PARA.TAB: I think it is a great shame that the ALP was not big enough to allow the full motion to be debated in this chamber so that people on this side of the Senate could have had the opportunity to speak. I am sure a number of senators on the other side would have liked to speak on it as well. I think this is very important because of the catastrophe that was faced by New South Wales at that time.

As the fires were developing, an estimate was made as to the possible losses. Thousands of homes could have been destroyed. The way the fires were going, that was the estimate. Hundreds of lives could have been lost. That the number was kept to a minimum is really to the great credit of the people who were involved. They should therefore be properly acknowledged in this chamber.

The fire touched so many lives, just as it nearly touched my life many years ago. One of my earliest memories as a boy is standing in the backyard of my home with a wet hessian bag waiting for pieces of fire to drop. As they dropped, we would charge over and put them out with the hessian bag. That was in the town of Eden in 1951 when the bushfires were raging up from Victoria. We were very fortunate in being in a town that was on the coast. Another of my earliest memories as a boy is being out on the beach with all the people from the town and all their furniture—beds, cupboards and the lot—as the fire raced for the town. The town had an old petrol dump in the middle of it. In those days petrol was in 44-gallon drums. There were hundreds and hundreds of these in a yard in the centre of the town. We were just waiting for the town to go up. Fortunately, the wind changed and that did not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that when Greenseas developed smoked tuna?

—Greenseas was there in a big way in those days. I had the same unfortunate experience six years later in the small town of Bargo on the southern tablelands. Again, fire raced for the town. My parents were out fighting the fires. I have a vivid memory of my two brothers and I sitting in a room playing canasta at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. Outside it was jet black from the smoke caused by the fires. Again the wind changed. It was just as well, because there was no beach. Being 40 kilometres inland, we would have had nowhere to go.

PARA.TAB: I have always had a very healthy respect for bushfires, but I did not really appreciate their awesome power until the January fires in New South Wales, which were the worst fires ever. I had the opportunity as a senator to fly over them while I was doing other tasks. Looking down on these massive fire systems, I appreciated how incredibly difficult it was to do anything about them. The Royal National Park south of Sydney—the second oldest national park in the world—looked like a moonscape. There was not one vestige of green left. Ku-ring-gai Chase was a wall of flame on the evening we flew over it. The flames stretched from the Pacific Ocean right across to the Brooklyn bridge. In one direction it was headed for the Hawkesbury and, in the other direction, it was headed for the northern suburbs of Sydney.

At that time people talked about the Ku-ring-gai Chase fire, the Gosford fire and the Peats Ridge fire but, when looking down on the area from the air, there was one huge fire system through the Hawkesbury valley, which was almost impossible to stop. We need to come to terms with what we are dealing with in this country and the real nature of the environment.

Floods, drought and bushfires are part of the natural system. We have to be better prepared at a national level so that we can provide the resources that are necessary to back up the excellent efforts at the state and local levels with more training, more equipment and more strategic planning.

Firefighting, even with all of this, is difficult at the best of times, but it was even more difficult this time because fuel levels were allowed to build up due to the misguided efforts of a lot of dark greens. They protested—they will claim that they did not, but all the local organisations tell me that they did—whenever anyone wanted to burn off to get rid of these fuel levels. Fuel levels across the country were allowed to build up to a horrific level, and the result was the disaster that occurred in January.

We are certainly not doing anything positive for the environment of this country or protecting the animals or plants if we end up with the fires that totally burnt out Ku-ring-gai Chase and the Royal National Park. It is better to do control burning. We must never put so many people's lives at risk unnecessarily because the burning has not been carried out.

People were prepared to take risks during that fire. I was truly proud at the time because I believe they defined the essence of what it means to be Australian. Our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has tried to redefine this in various ways. He has tried to change the flag and the constitution, but I think he misses the point. The essence of what it means to be an Australian stood in stark relief before him last January, silhouetted against the flames of the bushfire. Thousands of men and women dropped everything in early January—they left their jobs and their loved ones and risked their lives for others. It was in the same spirit of the pioneers who first came to this country, it was in the same spirit at the time of war, and it was in the same spirit at the times of hardship that have faced this country. People were looking out for each other; they were looking after their mates.

It was a privilege to join with those who paid tribute to the courage and the commitment of the people in the Hunter Valley, Dungog and Maitland when we met most recently. It was particularly a pleasure to pay tribute to the government of John Fahey, his minister Terry Griffiths, Chief Fire Commissioner of New South Wales, Phil Koperberg, and their staff who stopped the New South Wales fires from turning into a catastrophe.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the non-controversial matter of tobacco. Although it is non-controversial, it is certainly providing a lot of problems for growers in North Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria. The tobacco industry is a vital source of employment and income to parts of northern Australia and is the mainstay of the area around Mareeba and Dimbulah.

PARA.TAB: The tobacco industry was one of the industries that opened up North Queensland. The government started the tobacco industry as an import replacement industry. People were encouraged to come to the area and take up selections to grow tobacco in the 1930s and 1940s. The Tinaroo dam and canal systems were built to sustain the industry. Out of all this government encouragement, a vital industry developed. The area prospered, the north was developed, and the industry became the mainstay for a diverse, cosmopolitan region as many European migrants were attracted to the area—Albanians, Greeks and many others.

Sadly, for the last 10 years the industry has been in decline. It has rationalised itself, with over half the growers in North Queensland leaving the industry. The tobacco industry in recent years has also suffered the vagaries of decreasing production through health campaigns and massive government taxes. Both state and federal governments have used tobacco as a giant revenue source. Just last year, the Commonwealth collected excise of $4 billion, and Queensland had an extra $18 million windfall. Taxes are significant in that not only do they reduce consumption, which is falling at six per cent a year, but also governments directly gain extra revenue to fund worthwhile community programs such as increased education and health facilities. A breakdown of the tax from an average pack of cigarettes gives $1.22 to the federal government, $1.70 to the state government, $1.01 to the manufacturer, 80c to the retailer, and 0.06 of a cent to the grower.

I want to address the issue of the tobacco industry today not from the health issue—an important but entirely different issue—but from the angle of the tobacco industry as a primary industry that has become established and sustained rural communities for the last 70 years. The tobacco industry presently operates under the tobacco industry stabilisation scheme which is due to end in September 1995. Under the scheme, growers' quotas are set. These quotas have declined way below the industry's capacity to produce 16 million tonnes. Just over the last two years, growers' quotas have been reduced by 42 per cent to 8.1 million kilograms and are expected to continue to decline next season. The industry presently operates under a mixing regulation supported by the three cigarette manufacturers as well as the growers whereby local tobacco forms 57 per cent of the tobacco used by manufacturers.

However, the industry has just been dealt a further blow with the high quota levels submitted by the government under our schedule to the GATT Uruguay Round resolution. The government has submitted a tariff quota level for tobacco entering Australia at a concessional rate of 11.184 million kilograms or 70 to 80 per cent of local consumption. Both the manufacturers and the growers have said that this figure is too high and have said so to the government.

The GATT process was meant to convert the local content provision which stands at 50 per cent to a tariff rate. But the effect of it being based on the 1986 to 1988 levels and not the more recent years, which more accurately reflects declining consumption, means that Australian growers will have 70 per cent or more of their market open to imports. This is a most unfair consequence of the GATT solution.

The industry was assured by Minister Kerin when negotiations first started that it had nothing to fear, that it would not be left in a worse position. There is an Industry Commission inquiry presently under way, to be followed by a task force, but the damage has already been done to the industry by the high tariff quota level agreed by the government.

It is predicted that by the year 1996, when the full effect of the tariff quota is being felt, Australian producers will be reduced to contributing three million kilograms, a small quantity even when compared to the much reduced 8.1 million kilograms this season. That will be a reduction of around 70 to 80 per cent of the previous quota and will result in a reduction of their income of the same proportion.
It is not that the Australian tobacco industry is an inefficient industry. The recently released Tobacco Research and Development Council report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Prices achieved are the only guide available to portray the movement in crop quality and it is pleasing to see the upward trend.
It is also reported that, as production decreases, so does research and development funding, just when it is most needed.
The industry realises that half the growers will have to exit for the other half to survive. They need help to restructure and they need time to convert to other crops.

PARA.TAB: In Queensland it is not simply a matter of switching to rice or sugar, as the soil requirements are quite different, but there may be other crops that, once researched, can be used as replacement industries for some of these growers. Most importantly, towns such as Mareeba and Dimbulah, that have been legitimately based on the tobacco industry, cannot be allowed to suffer and die.

Last year the tobacco industry contributed $50 million to the Mareeba area. Mareeba has already taken the full brunt of the wet tropics declaration, resulting in the closure of its timber industry and the loss of hundreds of jobs. It has not benefited from the growth of tourism in the coastal area. It is a town hanging on the revival of the tobacco industry and the introduction of new replacement primary industries.

Towns such as Mareeba and Dimbulah are solid towns supporting the region. They provide good private sector services, essential medical services and financial services. Their continued healthy survival is essential for the far-flung beef industry and the people and industries of the far north and north-west of Queensland.

The government must take some responsibility for the situation now faced by the towns which support the tobacco industry. Tobacco growers are hardworking farmers growing a legal crop in a mechanised and advanced way. Each tobacco farm is a high level employer, employing around eight workers at harvest time. The industry is a valuable contributor to the economic health of the entire nation, as well as the areas where tobacco is grown. The industry is now facing a crisis. Although normal market changes are having their effect, it is the extremely high import tariff quota of 11.184 million kilograms that has been set that is hanging like a death threat over the industry.

Australian growers have to compete against highly supported industries overseas. Japanese growers are guaranteed $17 a kilogram when our growers receive $6.03 a kilogram. Major exporters such as Zimbabwe and Malawi benefit from massive devaluations of their currencies, and the US in the lead-up to the Uruguay Round resolution imposed a 75 per cent local content rule on its tobacco industry as a massive support scheme for its tobacco growers.

The Australian tobacco growers find themselves in a serious position—one caused by factors beyond their control. Serious consideration must be given to government funding to restructure the industry. It is most important that this be done over a sufficient period of time so that new agricultural industries can prove their sustainability and viability.

While hoping the Industry Commission and task force will bring some sought after solutions to the industry, it seems that any tariffication is still stuck with the high 70 per cent to 80 per cent tariff import quota level that the industry must now wear. Growers have been left in a seriously damaged financial position as a consequence of the GATT Uruguay Round. Consequently, the government must take a special interest in the future of the industry.

A smaller domestic industry can survive. However, around 50 per cent of the industry must leave. This restructuring must be done in stages, giving the industry and towns time to adjust. They cannot restructure all at the one time. Government funds must be provided for buyouts at the appropriate times.

As with some other rural industries, tobacco has been badly hurt by the much higher levels of the 1986-88 quotas being used. Tobacco is only a small industry and gains for other rural industries from the Uruguay Round do not provide much comfort when it is their industry that is bearing a very unfair burden of production cuts.

The industry is to be subject to the loss of its mixing regulations next year. I put it to the government that before this happens the tobacco industry must have in place a restructuring program that allows the industry to survive in a viable form and that allows growers who must leave the industry a future in other rural industries that have been tried and proven.

The future of the tobacco industry is certainly a case where the government must take responsibility for the state it now finds itself in. I look forward to the government accepting its responsibility in a constructive way.

Private sector consumption and stock building were by far the largest two contributors to growth in the December quarter—contributions of 1.1 percentage points and 0.7 percentage points respectively to the expenditure measure of GDP. Net exports contributed a further 0.4 percentage points—evidence of the significant structural improvement which has been achieved in Australia's external accounts. In contrast, public sector consumption was merely 0.2 percentage points.

Business investment was neutral in terms of growth in the December quarter. My question concerns the select committee established by the Senate to inquire into, among other things, whether the Prime Minister influenced or sought to influence those decisions of the Foreign Investment Review Board relating to the increase in permissible foreign ownership of the Fairfax newspaper group. What is the attitude of the Prime Minister and the government to the revelation that the chairman of the committee, Senator Alston, himself applied pressure to the editor of the Age newspaper to change editorial policy while being responsible for a committee examining the propriety of what is alleged to be exactly the same behaviour? Is it the government's belief that Senator Alston should stand down and, if so, why?

—There are many different kinds of Senate committee hearings and inquiries and in some of them it has to be expected that partisan political considerations will prevail and the committee will not meet judicial or even quasi-judicial standards. When a Senate committee is looking at the question of propriety or impropriety, when it is passing judgment on the conduct of individuals, when it is passing judgment on business decisions that affect the credibility and the viability of particular companies, then it is absolutely crucial that the highest standards of propriety be adhered to by the committee and by all those associated with it. That is why the revelations about the actions of Senator Alston are so serious and why the government believes he should step down as Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in relation to the Print Media.

PARA.TAB: We have here a situation in which the inquiry, of which Senator Alston is chairman, is determining three central questions: whether there were conditions attached to the approval of an increase in foreign ownership to the effect that Fairfax coverage had to be balanced; if so, did Fairfax act on the basis of any such arrangement; and, if so again, what was the propriety of such conduct or arrangement. Against that background, we now have revelations of Senator Alston ringing a Fairfax editor on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition complaining of bias and demanding balanced coverage, and doing so at a time when he was exercising real power in determining the outcome of an inquiry that was crucial to Fairfax's commercial reputation.

So, whatever Senator Alston's intentions may have been when making that particular phone call, it has all the appearances of a trade-off situation—`If you want a reasonable outcome from this inquiry which I am running, then you had better give us the kind of coverage we want'. That is certainly the way it would have been perceived on the newspaper side of the equation.

I stress that what matters here is what Senator Alston can be seen to have done. We do not know what his actual intention was. It may be, as the Fairfax editor Alan Kohler was saying, he was just plain dumb. But in all the appearances here, Senator Alston stands accused of hypocrisy and double standards as a result of his doing the very thing that he is complaining about in others. Unless he stands down, he can rightly and justly be accused of bringing the Senate committee system into disrepute. In the government's view, he should stand down immediately.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I refer to the reports on Chief Justice Mason's comments on the High Court's role in the development of a bill of rights. Since that role is of necessity a limited one, I ask the minister: does the government have any plans to introduce a bill of rights? Would it consider using the Canadian model where a legislative bill of rights was in use for 20 years before it was submitted to and passed by a constitutional referendum?

—The first thing I should say to Senator Spindler and to the Senate is that the government has no plans at this stage to seek to amend the constitution to enshrine a bill of rights, or indeed to follow the Canadian example and enact a legislative bill of rights. As members of the parliament, and particularly members of the Senate, would be well aware, there have been several attempts to provide for a bill of rights, either by way of amending the Australian constitution or through ordinary legislation. These attempts have failed in the face of concerted opposition.

PARA.TAB: Need I remind the Senate that the last time we had legislation before us to introduce a bill of rights into this country, we got to about clause 4 after 38 hours of debate—and I say to the Australian Democrats that they aided and abetted in this delaying of that legislation. Four clauses in 38 hours in pursuing legislation to introduce a bill of rights is something that this place can never be proud of. That delay at the time was recognised by most commentators as being fatal to that process.

The government recognises the importance of a bill of rights and its importance in providing a means for protecting and advancing the human rights of individuals. We have had an ongoing commitment to ensure that all Australians exercise and enjoy their human rights, and that the interests of individuals and minorities are not sacrificed at the will of the majority. If one looks at our record, since coming to office some 10 years or so ago the government has established national human rights machinery to assist in the domestic protection of human rights. We have outlawed race discrimination, sex discrimination, sexual harassment, and disability discrimination. We have established the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission. We have ensured the right to privacy and we have created the office of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. All those initiatives are quite important and fundamental in the protection of human rights in this country.

But apart from that domestic agenda that we have implemented—apart from the domestic machinery we have put in place—we have also, in the last few years, allowed individuals who feel that their human rights have been violated, and who have exhausted domestic remedies, to complain to the relevant international bodies under various international treaties, such as the International Covenant on Civil and Political rights, the race discrimination convention, and the torture convention. These complaint mechanisms available now to Australian citizens allow our domestic law to be scrutinised and measured against international standards.

The government has had a commitment to pursue the protection of human rights in this country. We have expressed that commitment in a number of ways. We have introduced legislation in this parliament to do the sorts of things that Senator Spindler talks about. As I say, the last attempt was frustrated after only getting to clause 4 of the bill after 38 hours of debate. Let me repeat what I said at the start: we have no plans at this stage to seek to amend the constitution to enshrine a bill of rights, or indeed to follow the Canadian example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister should know that the Australian Democrats have always supported the introduction of a bill of rights, including the one that the government introduced. Our only concern then was that it was not strong enough. Since we can now assure the government of our support for a proper, strong bill of rights, would it perhaps reconsider? In view of the foreshadowed support, would the government indicate its willingness to consider introducing a bill of rights again?

—When the bill of rights last came before this parliament, there were indeed aspects of the bill of rights that were being discussed. Let me repeat what I said earlier: the failure of that bill of rights to go through this parliament at a normal rate of progress was, I think, fatal to its chances of success—that was recognised at the time. The Democrats were part of the process when this chamber took 38 hours to debate four clauses. They stood by and allowed that process to continue, knowing full well that the end result of that delay, that filibustering, would be the failure of that bill of rights. That responsibility has to be met by them. They come in and say they are prepared to support a strong bill of rights, but no-one is going to fall for the trick of introducing legislation on the never-never.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to reports in today's press that the memorial to HMAS Canberra has become the latest target of vandals spray-painting public buildings, monuments and schools. Could the minister advise the Senate of the government's view regarding this type of activity and, in particular, the targeting of war memorials?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL; VETERANS' AFFAIRS; SPORT AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the acts of vandalism to which Senator Childs refers. They have occurred not only in Can

ANSWER.PARA: berra but in other places in recent days. Needless to say, the government profoundly deplores such acts of vandalism, as it does acts of vandalism of any kind, regardless of the motivation of those who are responsible for them. I do not think there can be any greater affront to decency than the desecration of memorials to those who have risked and given their lives in the service of their country in war.

PARA.TAB: I am certain that the Australian nation as a whole, with its broad base of cultures and experience, would also deplore such desecration of war memorials, especially the one we have in Canberra, which commemorates people who have made an immense sacrifice on behalf of their country. This particular memorial singled out for vandalism in Canberra commemorates those who died aboard HMAS Canberra in the Second World War. Veterans' organisations have been very quick to make plain to me their sense of absolute outrage at this particular desecration.

I am sure that the Australian people will join with the government, ex-service organisations, other veterans' organisations and the families which are affected by the desecration of that memorial to HMAS Canberra in expressing our absolute and utmost disgust and contempt for those who have committed this act and for those who are inclined to senselessly vent their anger on such important symbols of our national heritage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to the imminence of yet another of his taxpayer-funded ministerial travel extravaganzas, this time for three weeks in April to Indonesia, Singapore, Hong Kong, China, the United Kingdom, Switzerland, Germany and the Netherlands. If the minister is so intent on performing radical surgery on Medicare, how can he possibly afford to be away for three crucial weeks in the countdown to the budget?
—Because he is not dumb like you.

—If that is his best excuse, then we will pursue it further. Is it because he is so confident that his health package will not get rolled or is he simply exploring a wider choice of ambassadorial posts?
—It staggers me that Senator Alston has always been so interested in my travel plans. I think I was one of the few ministers not to have been away during last year. Senator Collins did all right.
—I was making up for you.
—That is right. Senator Cook was making up for me!
—Will you stay at the Ritz this time?

—I have never stayed at the Ritz; so I would not know about that. On this trip, I am going to talk to my counterpart in Indonesia. I was invited to China some time ago. A number of Australian companies which want to do some business in China wish to accompany the health minister on that trip. The rest of the trip will be spent in Switzerland and in the United Kingdom looking at the pharmaceutical industry and the cost of pharmaceuticals.

PARA.TAB: At the moment we have many examples of extraordinarily expensive drugs. One of the big problems to face the health system will be whether or not we can actually afford to accept the kinds of prices that the companies are asking for them. We will look to those drug companies to see how much justification they can give for the prices they are now charging. Given that the cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme runs into more than a billion dollars—it will be close to $2 billion this year—I do not think that is an unreasonable thing to do. That having been said, I can only say that I agree with Mr Kohler's assessment of Senator Alston—he is just dumb.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the minister gave feeble explanations for visiting a couple of places, but he did not mention the other six; in particular, Hong Kong, to which we know he is absolutely addicted. What is the purpose and estimated cost of this latest round-the-world romp? How is it any more relevant to Australians than the minister's $130,000 European junket in 1991, when the taxpayer was required to finance such essential services as a $4,000 a day motorcade across Ireland with his mate Brian Burke?

—I could not actually hear the last bit of the question about Brian Burke. I do not know what Senator Alston said about him, but then again I do not really care. The rest of the question regarded justifying each place that I went to. Senator Alston mentioned Hong Kong. I am going there at the end, which I am going to pay for. It is not going to cost the government anything. So what?
—You always go there.

—I have not been there for a long time and I would like to be there again. I will have a day or two there on the way back to Australia, which I will pay for. It will not cost Senator Alston anything, so I do not know what he is worried about.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer the minister to the treasury department's approval for the McArthur River mine project in the Northern Territory, which followed advice provided by the previous minister for the environment, and the release of the McArthur River project environment management plan for construction. Is the minister aware that the proponent of the mine has proposed substantially altering the location and design of the mine's port facility? Is the minister aware that the company is yet to fulfil at least 20 of the 36 recommendations of the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory upon which the approval was based? Why has the government allowed the construction of the project to commence before the environmental management plans are completed? What action is the minister going to take to enforce the conditions of the approval? Has the minister considered seeking a review of this project under the administrative procedures of the Environmental Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act? If not, why not?

—In answer to the first part of the question, I am aware of the changes. I am advised that the location of the barge loading facility has been moved about three kilometres west; however, the EIS studies did cover a range of possible sites, and the new location was within the area studied.

PARA.TAB: No site-specific environmental issues arose out of the assessment process. The new site is not expected to give rise to new environmental issues or different impacts. Impacts of the facility and associated dredging on seagrass beds and prawn fisheries were examined as part of the EIS process, and the Northern Territory government made recommendations for further studies in regard to these impacts. I am advised that these studies are addressed in the draft dredging environmental management plan. The EMP provides for the monitoring and management of impacts. For example, impacts on seagrass beds will be managed as part of that monitoring process. I understand that the changes to the design of the facility were in response to a recommendation by the Northern Territory government that the length of the causeway originally proposed be minimised. This causeway has now been eliminated to reduce impacts on longshore drift.

In terms of the 20 of 36 recommendations, that is a matter for the Northern Territory government. They are its recommendations. However, I am advised that the Northern Territory government considers that the recommendations are being appropriately addressed. It should be recognised that the environmental assessment process does not stop once approval has been given for a project. Many of the Northern Territory recommendations are ongoing for the life of the project or only relevant at later stages of development.

Ongoing environmental impacts will be managed through the EMPs required for the project. The completion of all the environmental management plans was not a prerequisite for the commencement of construction. The development of EMPs is an iterative process, and it is not reasonable or necessary to hold up all construction activities during this process.

The Commonwealth was involved in the project because of the requirement for foreign investment. The Commonwealth conditions require approved EMPs to be made available to the public and for the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency to be consulted on the EMPs. They also require wave and climatic conditions for barge loading operations to be specified.

My department has advised me that these conditions are being met. EMPs, once approved by the Northern Territory government, are available to the public, and the Commonwealth EPA is being consulted on draft EMPs. I understand that wave and climatic conditions will be specified in the EMP dealing with the transport of concentrate expected later in the year.

However, I have some concerns about the public availability of EMPs, and I have written to Mount Isa Mines in this regard. I have also sought an assurance that comments by the Commonwealth EPA on the draft dredging EMP will be fully addressed. I will advise that, if the plans are not modified after they have been addressed, I will look at further Commonwealth action, including action that could be taken under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, which is the last part of your question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I thank the minister for his answer. I ask a supplementary question relating to the implications of the dredging of the seagrass beds that are the most significant dugong breeding site in the whole of the southern hemisphere. I ask whether the implications of the Native Title Act 1993 have been considered in looking at the effect of this proposal on the particular area, in the light of the barge loading facility that is being proposed and the changes that have been made, which will shift it but may well shift it into an even more significant place from an environmental, as well as an Aboriginal sacred site, consideration.

—I have answered the part about the environmental issue because, according to my advice, the original assessment did include the broader area, including the area that it has now been moved to. But I do not know the answer in respect of native title. I will have to find that out and let Senator Chamarette know either today at the end of question time or tomorrow.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Now that the Australian Federal Police have completed their investigation into the Griffiths sandwich shop affair and subsequently charged Gordon Lennox with forgery and fraud under the Crimes Act, when is the Prime Minister going to announce the long-awaited second inquiry, personally requested by Mr Griffiths?
—I am not sure precisely when, but quite soon.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Having regard to the fact that it is now almost two months since Mr Griffiths's resignation, is the government now seeking to delay the inquiry until all legal action against Mr Lennox is completed? If so, why has the government changed its original approach?

—We are not seeking to delay the inquiry until all those legal proceedings have been concluded. But there are some complications that do involve the possible questioning of people, which I know were the subject of some discussion between the police and the Prime Minister's office. What the outcome of those discussions was I am not sure, but I know it is not the Prime Minister's intention to delay that inquiry. It is in everybody's interests that the issues outstanding be resolved as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence and relates to the Australian Defence Force contingent serving with the United Nations operations in Somalia. Can the minister advise the Senate whether the government has any plans to extent its current deployment?

—The government has decided to continue and expand slightly Australia's contribution to the United Nations peacekeeping operation in Somalia. Honourable senators will be aware that Australia has supported the UN in Somalia from the outset in October 1992. The government's decision means that Australia's contribution to UNOSOM will rise from 53 to 67 personnel.

PARA.TAB: The current force of 35 movement control officers, eight headquarters staff and 10 air traffic controllers will be replaced for a further six months. In addition, we will send a four-person airfield management team to work at Mogadishu airport. In view of the risks involved for our personnel, we are also sending 10 Army personnel as a protection unit to provide security for the contingent.

With the withdrawal of the major contingents, UNOSOM has undergone significant changes in its composition and mission. Its mandate has been amended and it is now focusing on providing security for distribution of humanitarian aid. There is no doubt that UNOSOM continues to face a difficult task. However, we believe that the cause is a worthy one. The plight of the Somali people has been truly appalling. The government's decision to renew Australia's commitment underlines its firm support for UNOSOM's continuing efforts to re-establish law and order and help create a new Somalia administered by the Somalis themselves. UNOSOM's mandate calls for the operation in Somalia to be completed by March 1995. Our continuing involvement will be reviewed later this year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. In the light of the minister's failure to answer my question yesterday, can he now tell the Senate, firstly, whether a 1990 AFP report concluded as follows:

QUESTION.PARA: There is little doubt that Italian organised crime syndicates have penetrated a number of government and non-government agencies and at least one political party in Australia.
Secondly, what action did the government take on this report? Thirdly, if it took no action, on what basis did the minister reject the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone once again refers to a report. She should know, as other members of this place would know, that intelligence reports are not produced for government but are internal reports related to proper criminal intelligence analysis processes within law enforcement agencies. Therefore, contrary to what she understands and expects, I am not in a position to confirm or deny the existence of a report of the nature referred to by Senator Vanstone. I can say that the matters she has raised were canvassed in the Winchester inquiry and, as I said yesterday, Coroner Winchester—
—Who?
—Coroner Winchester?
—Coroner Cahill, without interference from anyone, was able to exhaustively pursue those matters in his inquiry into the Winchester matter.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see that Senator Woods is now here to enhance the contribution of the other side. As I said yesterday, in addressing that evidence Coroner Cahill made very clear what he thought of the source of that evidence, and he made comments about Mr Verducci, the source of that evidence. Coroner Cahill said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . Mr Verducci was evasive, contradictory and . . . willing to say anything that would serve his purpose. He freely conceded that he was prepared to lie and had done so on many occasions.

The sorts of matters that Senator Vanstone is concerned about were investigated by Coroner Cahill in the Winchester inquiry without the result that she alleges. Not only are the allegations outlandish, but also the government has been keen to pursue allegations relating to Italian organised crime—a matter which Senator Vanstone should also know. We have given a reference on Italian organised crime to the National Crime Authority. It is matter No. 14, and was referred in June 1992. As a member of the NCA parliamentary joint committee, Senator Vanstone would know this. She would also know in respect of that reference that there has been no political interference—no interference by the government—with the NCA or the AFP in terms of its investigations.

PARA.TAB: Referring that matter to the NCA is reflective of the government's ongoing commitment to pursue organised crime as far as it is within our capacity on a state or federal level. Senator Vanstone would also know that the NCA, in adopting that inquiry, has done so through a mechanism which involves both state and federal operations. Investigations are flowing from that reference. They have been undertaken in most jurisdictions in Australia and have been coordinated by the NCA. That reference in respect of Italian organised crime is supported by all governments in Australia and is getting results.

The government is determined to fight organised crime in this country and internationally. If Senator Vanstone is patient, she will appreciate that the inquiry I referred to is important in that respect and she will very soon see the Minister for Justice announcing the government's response to the recently completed review of Commonwealth law enforcement arrangements. As all senators should appreciate, we are aware of the need to pursue organised crime. Our determination is to fight it in all its manifestations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister seems to confuse today, as he did yesterday, the allegation that a 1990 AFP report has come to this conclusion with some sort of remarks that may have been made by Mr Verducci in the Winchester inquiry. The Winchester inquiry was not charged with the responsibility of ascertaining the veracity of the allegation that government and non-government agencies have been infiltrated by Italian organised crime, nor with ascertaining the veracity of the allegation that a major Australian political party has been so infiltrated. So the minister's answer, to that extent, is deficient, because that was not the task of the Winchester inquiry. I come back to the original question: does the government accept the allegation made in the AFP report? If it does not accept the allegation made in the AFP report, is the minister saying that the AFP was simply wrong and incompetent in drawing the conclusions that it did?

—I am not confusing anything; it is Senator Vanstone who refuses to accept the answer. What I have said in respect of that report is that intelligence reports are not produced for government; they are internal reports related to proper criminal intelligence analysis. That has always been the case. What I have said about the matters Senator Vanstone referred to in respect of those reports is that, firstly, they were pursued by Coroner Cahill; secondly, they are pursued by the continuing reference—
—It is not good enough.

—What does Senator Vanstone mean, it is not good enough? We have instituted a reference through the National Crime Authority, at state and federal levels, to pursue this particular matter. That matter is going on without interference. The NCA, through the IGC, has never asked for a reference which this government has refused to give it. Senator Vanstone should acknowledge that as well. The matters have been pursued; they are being pursued; and they are being pursued without political interference. Any degree of muckraking that Senator Vanstone wants to get into at the moment does not hold water, because the NCA inquiry is a very firm example of the government's resolve to pursue organised crime without interference.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. During the last election the government gave a commitment to improve the incentives for unemployed people to take up part-time or casual work. Can the minister advise the Senate of the progress in implementing this commitment.
—Is this one of the few election promises that the government has kept?

—I am very pleased to be able to tell the Senate that as from next Monday, 21 March, unemployed people will be able to earn more money from part-time and casual work while continuing to be able to receive unemployment payments. This is as a result of introducing the earnings credit scheme, which is similar to the one for social security pensioners.

PARA.TAB: From Monday, people getting jobsearch and newstart allowances will get a credit for every $90 each fortnight if they are single, or $80 for each partner of a couple, to count against their earnings for that fortnight. The credit will accumulate until it reaches a maximum figure of $500. In other words, if single people who are eligible to earn up to $90 a fortnight do not do that, they are able to amass a credit against their future earnings.

As I said, it will accumulate until it reaches a figure of $500. At any time while that amount accumulates, or until it reaches $500, people can have access to all or part of the credit for any earnings they make while in receipt of unemployment payments. As I stood up, Senator Kemp asked me if this was an election promise broken. No, Senator Kemp, this is an election promise made and kept, like so many others. Senator Kemp should not get upset; this is very good news.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. What I asked was: was this one of the few election promises that the government has kept? That is exactly what I said, Senator Crowley.
—That is not a point of order.

—One way or another, what is clear is that it is an election promise made and an election promise kept. It is going to assist unemployed people very significantly. It is at an estimated cost of $40 million in a full year. It means that there is an increased incentive and reward for unemployed people to look for and take up part-time or casual work without the same threat against their pension, particularly if they have this credit amassed. It is also going to be particularly useful for people who at the moment find that it is very hard to get full-time work but who are able to benefit from part-time and, particularly, casual or seasonal work.

PARA.TAB: The earnings credit will also be available to people receiving sickness allowance who, while not yet fit to return to full-time work, may be able to make a gradual or graded return to work through part-time or casual work. Once people leave the unemployed payment system, their accumulated credit will be preserved for up to 13 weeks, so the earnings credit will also be of benefit to those people who come on and off unemployment benefits looking for and enjoying sometimes the benefits of casual or seasonal work. The earnings credit very much assists people on unemployment benefits. It recognises that they are much better assisted towards returning to full-time work if they are able to have access to part-time or casual work. It is an excellent addition to people on unemployment benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the disclosure on the ABC program Lateline last night by the Director-General of ASIO, David Sadlier, that ASIO had detected and stopped a terrorist attack in Australia while it was in the planning stages within the last two years. What action was taken by ASIO against the alleged perpetrators, and was this action in any way related to the expulsion of Russian embassy staff last year?

—I can certainly answer the latter part of the question; no, it was not. As to the former, I have no further comment than that which was given by the Director-General of ASIO himself; namely, neither to confirm nor deny any further detail in relation to that. That is the view he took—it is a quite proper view—that he could not give any further detail. I cannot, nor can any other minister, add to that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I draw the minister's attention to the increasing level of anxiety in the community welfare sector about the current Industry Commission inquiry into charities and to the Treasurer's reply to a question on notice from Senator Patterson in December last year. Given that the budgets of most community welfare groups are already stretched to the limit in providing much needed services to the community, what funding will the government provide to enable charities, in the Treasurer's own words, `to have informal discussions with the commissioners, to prepare submissions, to attend public hearings and to comment on the draft report'? How will the government guarantee that scarce resources will not be diverted from meeting the desperate situation of Australians at the bottom of the heap by the need for charities to respond to the inquiry?

—It should be said from the beginning that it is my understanding that a number of charities favour this inquiry being conducted by the Industry Commission. The inquiry is, after all, into the efficiency of the delivery of services by the charities and the virtue of the idealism and intent and motive of people who work in charities. The concern is to see that the dollar received goes as far as it can to meet the needs of the recipients. So the Industry Commission inquiry into charities is directly welcomed by a number of them. It is about improving their service delivery and making sure that the dollar donated, or as much of that dollar as possible, goes to the people at the bottom of the heap who need those services.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the Industry Commission is satisfied that there should not be any significant cost to the charities for participating in the inquiry and that the Industry Commission is aware of the anxieties referred to in Senator Woodley's question. It will do its best to make sure that this inquiry does not result in costs of any significance being incurred by the charities; that is, it will be particularly sensitive about the group that it is now looking at to make sure that costs are minimised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his department's selling off of rifle ranges in various parts of Australia. I ask the minister: what method is the department using in the disposal of such ranges and what, if any, preference is given to an established rifle club or clubs that have been using those ranges for many years—up to 100 years?
—Is this a trawling exercise?

—As Senator Schacht says, a question like this is driftnet fishing at its best. I will have to refer this question to Senator McMullan, but from my knowledge of the area the department has been commercialised. In the context of that commercialisation, it has an obligation to obtain the best commercial result for the sale of its property. In dealing with individual rifle ranges, the rights of existing leaseholders are obviously taken into account. Quite often those leaseholders have long-term leases. If there is anything specific that Senator Panizza would like me to refer to Senator McMullan, I am sure I could do that for him.

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for what he has told me, but I would like him to find out about the rest of it. Senator Bolkus said that Senator McMullan's department is commercialised; I certainly agree with that. While he is making the inquiry, I would like him to find out why he is not able to offer those ranges to rifle clubs that have been using them, after evaluation by a licensed valuer, and why the ranges cannot be sold to the clubs if they wish to take the ranges at that valuation.

—I do not know the answer to this question because for the last half an hour I have been bemused by the list in the Sydney Morning Herald which tells me that Senator Panizza cannot decide who to support for his party's leadership. Quite honestly, my mind has been off questions such as this. He is being dragged down by the whip.

PARA.TAB: I am not so sure that what he said is not the case. From memory, quite often arrangements are made by existing leaseholders. I am sure that I will able to give him an answer to that question before he can decide who to support as his leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. I refer to the release yesterday of the latest Yellow Pages small business index which shows that confidence among Australian small businesses surged last quarter. Is the minister able to provide further information on the survey results? Do the results provide any indications on the strength of the economic recovery?

—I thank Senator Burns for his question because it follows on from the question and the answer given earlier today by Senator Cook outlining the very good December quarterly accounts figures. The Yellow Pages national index on small business activity, which has now been going for nearly a year on a quarterly basis, has already established itself, I think, as the pre-eminent indicator in the private sector of small business activity. PARA.TAB: As Senator Cook said, the national accounts figures are very good. This survey shows that the figures for small business are very good indeed. The businesses covered in this very good outcome are manufacturing, construction, wholesale, finance, recreation—and their subgroups.

The survey found that confidence in small business had surged during the December quarter. Of the small businesses, 31 per cent reported higher sales and 21 per cent reported higher profits. Nearly three-quarters of proprietors expressed confidence in their prospects. Also, 60 per cent of small businesses surveyed see economic recovery as being well under way. I know that figure will disappoint all senators opposite with the possible exception of Senator Boswell who I think, from my 12 months in the job, is the only senator opposite who genuinely raises issues of small business with me, both publicly and privately—and I acknowledge that.

TALK.START.PARA: —None of your colleagues do; is that correct?

—Of the other side, I said. Sixty-five per cent of small businesses expect the economy to be even better in one year's time—a further indication of doom and gloom, I suppose, to the opposition as we get closer to the next election. Employment in small businesses surveyed rose by one per cent in the quarter to February. Fifteen per cent of proprietors of small businesses expect to increase employment in the next three months. The survey gives the strongest indication that the most important part of the biggest employing sector of our economy—small business—is going ahead as the strongest part of our economy.
