The government certainly gives great credit to the small business sector for the work it has done to get the economy going, despite the harping and the doom and gloom coming from those opposite, with the exception of—(Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the minister advise what assurances, if any, he has received from the US Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, about US wheat sales in markets to which Australia also exports? Did discussions with Warren Christopher give any indication of America's willingness not to use credit sales or other inducements in an effort to skirt around the GATT agreement?

—Some of these issues were raised in the discussions with Secretary Christopher when he was in Australia a few days ago. The situation overall is this: the Uruguay Round disciplines on export subsidies will require a reduction of 36 per cent in budgetary terms and 21 per cent in terms of the volume of subsidised exports that will be permitted during the implementation period from 1995 to 2000. In the case of the US, for example, that will mean a reduction in value of subsidies on wheat and flour exports from $US846 million to $US364 million and a very significant reduction in volume from 21.4 million tonnes to 14.5 million tonnes.

PARA.TAB: We are aware that farm organisations in the US are pressing their government to convert export subsidy programs such as the EEP into some sort of tool for general market promotion. That would not enable the US to avoid its reduction commitments on export subsidies but would be a worrying development. It would certainly show to be empty the persistent claims that have been made by the US to the effect that it is a reluctant subsidiser and that it is in the export subsidy business only to protect its interests against unfair trading practices of other countries, particularly those in Europe.

The government has raised with the US administration its concern about all of those developments and also about what would happen so far as disposal of stocks is concerned, and I will come to that in a moment. We have raised that through our embassy in Washington and, as I have said, we have raised it in the discussions with Secretary Christopher.

In following up those discussions Senator McMullan, the Minister for Trade, has written to the US Secretary of Agriculture, Mr Espy, on this matter. He will also be raising the issue when he meets Mr Espy and the US trade representative, Mickey Kantor, at the Uruguay Round ministerial meeting—the wrap-up meeting—that is due to take place in Marrakech next month.

Might I say for the record that Senator McMullan was given an explicit assurance by the European external relations commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, that the EC would continue to act responsibly with regard to disposal of agricultural stocks in the period leading up to the implementation of the Uruguay Round disciplines in 1995. The period between now and then is really quite crucial. He also gave a commitment that the European Community would not initiate any escalation in export subsidies. The government is seeking parallel assurances on those matters from the United States. That is very much a part of the discussions that have occurred and will be followed up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the minister really got assurances that the Americans are prepared to match the rhetoric of GATT with action? It seems there are US interagency negotiations on trying to convert the export enhancement program to a market promotion program and to move into the GATT green box, as well as lobbying by commodity groups to ensure they get a better deal. How likely is the US government to capitulate to the pressures that are coming from the lobby groups in the US to make the market promotion program happen?

—The US has not got any choice but to observe the GATT disciplines during the period from 1995 onwards. There are two issues, and I addressed both of them in my reply. One is the question of what they do about stocks and so on in the period between now and the implementation of all the GATT disciplines from 1995 onwards. I addressed the other question about the possibility of converting exports subsidies under the EEP into a market promotion program in the first half of my reply, because that has been something that has been very much on our minds.

PARA.TAB: There is no reason to suppose that the Americans, when confronted with the international spotlight that these practices will be now under as a result of the conclusion of the Round negotiations, will not meet their obligations. They sometimes twist and wriggle a little in terms of getting to the barrier on these matters but once the obligation is set in concrete, is clearly determined, and the rules that are applicable are clear as they are now—or certainly will be with the establishment of the WTO—then I do not think there is any reason whatsoever to doubt the bona fides and credibility of our friends in the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. Countries all over the world are facing the growing phenomenon of illegal movements of people. What is Australia doing to address these problems at a regional level?

—I thank Senator Neal for her first question—and a good one at that. Senator Neal asks a question which relates to one of the world's most pressing problems, that is, the unprecedented illegal movement of people. It is an enormous issue, a world-wide one. The United Nations Population Fund has estimated that with the 100 million people on the move throughout the world today—the scale of today's migration being beyond that of previous experience—this problem is one that poses a whole raft of challenges. It poses challenges to governments all over the world. They are faced with the challenge of an increasing number of people seeking to move by illegal channels. It poses risks to the persons involved and also to the countries that carry them either by way of transit or as final destinations, including security and health risks.

PARA.TAB: This is a new phenomenon. We are seeing the growth of a particularly undesirable aspect of this phenomenon—the clandestine trade in illegal migrants known as people smuggling. This practice amounts to little more than slavery. It is slavery for those who pay large sums of money to smuggling gangs, many of whom have links with organised crime. Australia has had a long-term interest in this area. We share the concerns of nations which are trying to deal with the many problems associated with the large scale of illegal movements of people, the large scale of people smuggling. As a consequence, I am pleased to be able to announce that the Australian government will host a regional consultation on illegal migration in Canberra on 11 and 12 April 1994. The consultation will bring together some 18 participants from the Asia-Pacific region, as well as international organisations with major involvement in this area. Our objective in hosting this meeting is to begin a process which will enable the exchange of information and views between countries in the region, improve the flow of information, enable participants to define what they see as illegal migration, and demonstrate how illegal migratory movements manifest themselves. But, more importantly, we will discuss options for future action.

As we did with the comprehensive plan of action, we believe that the consultations have great promise in fostering a cooperative approach to what is a serious international problem. Taking this role helps to increase Australia's profile in the region. We have had enormous success with the CPA over recent years. We anticipate that by kicking off this process, Australia will once again be at the lead in confronting a problem which is confronted by nations world-wide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—On Monday of this week Senator Watson asked me whether I agreed that, for a five-year debenture involving a partnership or company, 1,826 separate calculations are required to compute the daily rate of return—or words to that effect. I took Senator Watson's question on notice and I now have an answer.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the office of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) has spoken to Senator Watson's office and has offered to brief him on the proposals contained in the government's discussion paper on accruals, Taxation of the financial arrangements. The discussion paper proposes that the core accruals method to be used by taxpayers who are within the scope of the proposed accruals tax system will be the compounding daily accruals method. Taxpayers who use this method will have to calculate a daily internal rate of return.

However, the discussion paper also proposes that, when certain conditions are satisfied, taxpayers will be able to use a simpler accruals method known as daily straight line accruals. The daily straight line accruals method requires one calculation to determine the income or deductions from a standard five-year debenture. A standard debenture which pays interest regularly at a fixed rate and which is not issued at a significant discount or premium would be susceptible to the simpler daily straight line accruals method.

It is likely, therefore, that a company or partnership involved in a five-year debenture of the type referred to by Senator Watson in his question will not have to calculate a daily internal rate of return. Even if a company or partnership involved in a five-year debenture has to calculate a daily internal rate of return, there is absolutely no need to perform 1,826 separate calculations to do so. Taxpayers in this situation could choose to perform 1,826 separate calculations, if they were so inclined, but it would be far simpler for them to compute the daily internal rate of return using a standard financial calculator or spreadsheet program.

A daily internal rate of return for a standard five-year debenture can be determined in a matter of seconds using a financial calculator. I have one in my hand. All I have to do is enter the periodicity of cash flows, enter those cash flows, press the internal rate of return or equivalent button—that is the button marked CST—and in a handful of seconds I have the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Show us.

—If honourable senators have to have a proper example, I will show them. I enter the periodicity of cash flows, enter those cash flows, then press the internal rate of return button and up pops the answer on this little screen. Some further adjustments may need to be made to this figure, depending upon factors such as the number of leap years in the term of the debenture, irregular spacing of coupon payments and the degree of precision required. Like the original calculation, this is quite straightforward.

PARA.TAB: Internal rate of return is a commonly used concept. Any business which has a choice of potential investments will take the internal rate of return implicit in those investments into consideration in making the investment decision. Companies and partnerships will be familiar with the internal rate of return calculations and will generally have the hardware—that is, the financial calculator or spreadsheet program—and the experience necessary to perform such a calculation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) to a question without notice asked by Senator Carr this day, relating to the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in relation to the Print Media.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this inquiry is essentially a farrago of appalling misjudgments. The very fact that the Select Committee on Foreign Ownership Decisions in the Print Media was established under the terms of reference that it was, suggested to me that there was a distinct possibility the committee would turn into a farce. When we look at a Senate committee which essentially is examining the propriety or impropriety of, and passing judgments on, the conduct of individuals or business decisions that affect the credibility and viability of particular companies, it is absolutely crucial that the operations of that committee are seen to be aboveboard. However, that has not been the case.

PARA.TAB: From the beginning of the operations of this committee on 9 March 1994 we were told there would be no witch-hunt. Assurances were given, both by the opposition and the Australian Democrats, that there would not be a witch-hunt and that issues of great substance would be considered. However, the establishment of this committee has demonstrated that to have been an act of misjudgment. The second act, I suppose, was the proposition that the chair be given to Senator Alston, a member of the opposition, which clearly has a political agenda to pursue, as evidenced by the way in which the matters have been under investigation.

The committee has demonstrated to us that it has been operating double standards. We have complained on many occasions about the way in which this committee has operated. We have indicated that we are not entirely happy with the breach of the conventions in the way in which these sorts of committees should operate. We have seen the threatening of public servants and, I believe, attempts to intimidate public servants and acts of misjudgment. We have also been given in recent times an indication by Senator Alston that he has the capacity to ring the editor of a newspaper, the Age, which is under investigation by this committee, and complain about that newspaper's editorial balance. We have been given the reference to look into that paper's content and the way in which it is operated. That act has been described as dumb.

In politics, one should not necessarily suggest that stupidity in itself is a reason for resignation. We know that if that were the case quite a few people in public life would have some difficulty. However, we do have a real problem with the intentions of Senator Alston. Whatever he claims were his intentions, his actions have given the committee the appearance of having been fundamentally compromised. We have a situation where the chairman of the committee at this time has more power at his disposal than he is ever likely to have.

A report to be brought down will comment upon the operations of John Fairfax Ltd and the actions of individuals with respect to their propriety. That raises some pretty basic questions about the way in which the committee should operate. When it is said that there should be some discussion and that questions of judgment should be exercised with respect to the transfer of ownership of Fairfax, it is important and absolutely fundamental that there is no hypocrisy from the chairman. There should also be no question of double standards. In this case, the chairman of this committee has indicated on the public record that he believes that these matters are clear and that a deal was done. He has prejudged the operations of the committee. We have seen the final act of misjudgment.

The question I put to Senator Evans today was based on my concern for the integrity of our committee. It really does raise the issue of how long this committee can continue. Quite clearly, it is in the interests of the operations of this committee—if it wants any integrity at all in the report—that Senator Alston stand down from the chair. I believe that there are very fundamental issues here that go to the question of propriety and the issue of hypocrisy. Acting on behalf of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), the chairman of this committee, at a time when he has more power than he is ever likely to have, is able to raise matters with editors about the question of balance, the very subject we are purporting to inquire into. It is quite clear, as far as I am concerned, that Senator Alston should stand down. Under the terms of reference that have been put through this Senate, another coalition member can take the chair. If there is to be any propriety or integrity in the way in which this committee operates, Senator Alston should stand down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to take particular note of the answer given by Senator Gareth Evans. I thought it was highly significant in a number of respects; in fact, it was quite measured. In some ways, I do not think he had his heart in it. For example, he did not seek to comment on the suggestion of a deal which, in the last day or so, has been elevated in yet another desperate attempt to suggest that somehow the Select Committee on Foreign Ownership Decisions in the Print Media is not behaving in the way that it should. On 18 November last year, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when in Seattle, in talking about Conrad Black, said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, we'll think about it, but we want a commitment from you that the paper will be balanced.
So therefore, after the election, I, on behalf of the Government made good a commitment to reconsider them, and took them to 25.

I do not think there is a need to say any more than that. We are talking about an agreement, a deal, a commitment—the words are all the same. I do not think anyone could quibble that it was secret because the matter emerged only after Mr Black revealed it on Lateline some months after the event. All I can say is that, if anyone has prejudged the outcome, it is Senator Loosley. On PM last night he very wisely said that there was no deal. He obviously has not read the transcript and, in all fairness, I think he ought to do that.

PARA.TAB: If we are talking about the way in which the committee has operated, it is worth remembering a couple of important things. This is very significant. There are a number of crucial matters of public importance. The whole role of the Foreign Investment Review Board and its effectiveness are crucial issues to public policy considerations in this country. Yet what we have had to date is, to say the least, a marked reluctance for any cooperation on the part of government. The Prime Minister treats the Senate committees with contempt. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) puts every obstacle in the way of the committee and declines any invitation to attend. Those who are on the committee, particularly Senator Loosley and Senator Carr, have no compunction about doing all that they can to derail the committee.

We will not be distracted or deterred. We understand what their political agenda is. It seems to me that today they are demonstrating beyond doubt that the committee is being effective in its work. We are not prejudging anything. We are not doing anything other than pursuing the terms of reference, and it is very important that we do that. I understand why they are desperate to undermine the committee. I do not quite understand however why Senator Loosley and Senator Carr should go out to the media and brief it comprehensively in the way they did after a private meeting of the committee had been held.
Senator Evans raised two matters. One was that I had brought pressure to bear on Mr Kohler. Let me just repeat Mr Kohler's lines:

SPEECH.PARA: He just rang up for a chat and it was quite a friendly kind of call, and he just said he had a few concerns about our coverage of the leadership issues. He thought that one or two of our reporters were running an agenda, and he just wanted to express that concern.
That is hardly pressure—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the quote about you being dumb?

—If those opposite want to use that sort of quote, they cannot have it both ways. They cannot say, `Well, Kohler was right in his assessment', but ignore the fact that Kohler said in no shape or form did he regard it as improper. He said, `I don't think he ought to resign. I don't think the committee is compromised. He didn't raise balance'—
—Where is the quote about you being dumb?

—Stop smiling, Senator Evans. This is serious. Unfortunately, those opposite have swallowed what poor old Senator Carr was not able to understand properly. Senator Carr said on AM the other morning, `We have the case of Senator Alston directly involved in asking for balance from a newspaper in this country'. As was explained very carefully to poor old Senator Carr in the committee meeting, that was not so. I did not ask for balanced coverage. Once again we have Mr Kohler confirming it—
—Is he telling the truth about you being dumb?
—Do not laugh at me. Just look at the transcript. We had Mr Kohler saying yesterday—he made it clear to me:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it was a point during a conversation, and I said to him, you know, `You're not asking me for balance, are you, Senator Alston?', and he laughed and said he wouldn't dream of asking such a thing. And it was kind of . . . there was a bit of that banter.

If that is the best evidence that those opposite have got that I was asking for balance, then Mr Kohler has comprehensively refuted it. I note that Senator Evans did not even touch the question of a deal and did not actually make judgments. Now those opposite are reduced to saying that there is some sort of appearance of conflict.

PARA.TAB: I am very sad that the Sydney Morning Herald was led to believe by Senator Loosley that the clerk had given evidence that there was a conflict of interest. The clerk was forced to respond to my letter. There was no explanation from Senator Loosley as to how that came about or apology from him for what was a grossly misleading statement that appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald. I notice that Senator Gareth Evans had the grace not to repeat that sort of calumny. All that he said was that there was an appearance of, and that accusations had been made—no convictions. I would have thought at the very least those opposite ought to take a guide from him. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak to the motion to take note of Senator Gareth Evans's answer to Senator Carr's question. Quite correctly, Senator Evans did raise the question about propriety. I would like to address that because it is a very important matter. This committee was set up on the motion of Senator Alston on behalf of the opposition. The committee's terms of reference went to particular matters, including:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) whether those decisions were influenced by considerations relating to the content of newspapers including any requirement for `balanced' coverage;
Paragraph (iv) stated:
(iv) whether the Prime Minister influenced or sought to influence those decisions, and, if so, the basis on which and the extent to which he did so;

On the question of what decision this committee is going to reach and hand down in the Senate, Senator Alston says that he has made no comment that would influence the outcome of any report. PARA.TAB: Senator Alston, on two occasions, has now publicly stated, in a conclusive way, that there was an agreement between the Prime Minister and Conrad Black. If it does not, then he does not have the support of his other committee members.

I support Senator Evans in saying that propriety clearly has been breached in this instance. We should not allow the committee to continue with a chairman who has not acted impartially. For that reason, he should not continue as the chairman of this committee. Senator Alston also said that he did not address the question of balanced reporting with Mr Kohler. He did say that to the committee. It is certainly my recollection, as a member of the committee, that he raised the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said it as a joke—flippantly.

—It may have been said flippantly, but the fact is that it was said. It is a very bad joke, and I know that Senator Kernot agrees it is a very bad joke. In terms of the subsequent letter that Senator Alston refers to that he received from Mr Kohler, one would have to wonder why Mr Kohler even wrote to Senator Alston. Supposedly it was because this article had been leaked to the Sunday Age and he wanted to clarify that it was not he who had leaked the article. One would have to wonder why Mr Kohler would do that without any request from Senator Alston. He all of a sudden wrote a letter saying, `Well, it wasn't me who told them'. I guess we could say that it seems to be a rather odd situation. My point is really that Senator Alston may have asked for that letter to be written.
—I certainly did not.
—Table the letter.

—Maybe it ought to be tabled, because it is a matter of whether it was written to Senator Alston as chairman of the committee or to him as a person. We come back to the issue that this committee chairman acted impartially with regard to the outcome. We should not lose sight of the fact that the committee's own terms of reference, written by Senator Alston, sought to determine whether or not there was any deal and whether or not there were any statements made. He cannot then publicly say conclusively that there were. He has an obligation to the committee and to the Senate to act impartially, and he has not done so. It is quite correct for Senator Evans to call for him to resign from the committee, and he should do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that the government senators on this committee ought to get their facts straight. I refer firstly to comments made by Alan Kohler yesterday on the World Today program on the ABC. He was interviewed in relation to this very matter. He said that Senator Alston contacted him in relation to the coverage by the Age of the leadership questions in the Liberal Party. He said that Senator Alston made it very clear that he was calling as shadow minister for communications and on behalf of John Hewson. Mr Kohler said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . during the conversation, and I said to him, you know, `You're not asking me for balance, are you, Senator Alston?', and he laughed and he said he wouldn't dream of asking such a thing. And it was kind of . . . a bit of that banter.

He is corroborating what Senator Alston said in relation to the joke that he made. It was a joke—and, in fact, Senator Alston was contacting Mr Kohler about something completely different. Mr Kohler revealed that during the previous week he had had three, four or five contacts from various politicians. He said, `It kind of goes on all the time'. In fact, Paul Kelly, who was interviewed on the same station, said:

Well, I don't know exactly what Senator Alston said, but I see absolutely nothing improper in that at all. I mean, it's going to be a sad and sorry day if we get to the stage where journalists or editors believe it's improper for politicians to ring them up.

I remind the government senators on the Senate Select Committee on Foreign Ownership Decisions in the Print Media to remember that the terms of reference do relate to specific matters. They relate to the origin and basis of decisions in 1991 and 1993 to increase the permissible percentage of foreign ownership of newspapers, and that would go up to about March 1993. They do not involve anything which has happened since then. For the government senators on this committee to suggest that members of the committee, including the chairman, are not at liberty to phone up an editor or a journalist in this country and say that they are not being properly treated or they are not being given accurate coverage is absolutely outrageous.

PARA.TAB: I would hate it if government senators ever served on a jury because I am damn sure they would not look at the facts of the matter before them. In this case the facts are before them and they should look at what Mr Kohler said. Mr Kohler said that in no way did he feel that any influence was being brought to bear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't he publish the story?

—He did not publish the story. He said he did not publish the story. He said that he put down the telephone and just got on with his work. PARA.TAB: Mr Kohler said that Senator Alston made it abundantly clear that he was approaching him on a matter completely separate to that which is under inquiry by this committee. Even Paul Kelly, when he was interviewed, thought that this was farcical. He said, `I would never complain about politicians, whatever committee they are heading, calling up and making their views known'. Undoubtedly, at one stage or another honourable senators in this chamber have called a journalist or an editor to make their views known. It is completely proper, in the process of democracy in this country, that honourable members exercise their roles as senators by contacting journalists and editors when they feel they have been hard done by. Every one of us has felt that an article has been unfair either to our party or ourselves. We are at liberty to call the journalist who wrote the article or the newspaper and put our view forward. Reading the terms of reference, government senators will see that those terms of reference have nothing to do with the subject about which Senator Alston telephoned Mr Kohler. Mr Kohler admits that; he fully corroborates Senator Alston. There is no case for Senator Alston to answer and, if government senators read the advice from the Clerk of the Senate, they too will realise that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also rise in the debate to take note of the answer given by Senator Gareth Evans. Really, Senate select committees ought not to be abused in this way; they ought not to become vehicles by which people can be abused. There is no doubt that this inquiry was conceived in political malice. I do not make that reference to the Australian Democrats because I understand Senator Kernot's principal concern rested with the workings of the Foreign Investment Review Board and foreign investment policy generally. It would have been far better had there never been the political malice demonstrated in respect of the Fairfax takeover and had the foreign investment questions been dealt with separately by a Senate standing committee with all the processes of due deliberation and care. It would have been an infinitely better circumstance.

PARA.TAB: The situation we now have is that the Select Committee on Print Media, Foreign Ownership Decisions has become a continuing embarrassment to the opposition rather than to the government because of the behaviour of the chair. I will not make personal references. What has been going on is just plain silly: the manner in which the government was excluded from the loop of information, the way in which people waltzed into the Senate and moved motions without consulting the committee and now political intervention.

There is no problem with Senator Alston talking to the editor of the Age per se. There is no problem with him talking to journalists per se. Most people do that. Senator Kernot, who says she does not, is learning fast, I am sure. The simple issue is political intervention, that in respect to the phone call to Mr Kohler, the editor of the Age, Senator Alston did not tell the committee the whole story. He did not tell us the complete and unalterable truth. He never mentioned the fact that Dr Hewson had asked him to make the call. Mr Kohler mentioned and put that on the World Today. We have all read the transcript.

Then we come to the circumstances of why the Age exercised self-censorship. The story does not appear for days until someone else within the organisation hears about it by way of the corridor. The committee is now farcical. It has become flawed. It has been characterised by partisanship, by incompetence and by foolishness. Matters may or may not be coming to a head this evening in terms of the standards that should apply to the chair of a Senate select committee. A single standard ought to be maintained for everybody on both sides of the chamber. It is not good enough for people to insist on the highest standards of office for the government while the coalition simultaneously maintains the standards of high farce. It is simply not good enough. There ought to be a single standard.

When Senator Alston was quoted twice in the last 24 hours—he may have said it on other occasions, but I have only seen two quotes—I really thought that a deal had been done, an arrangement had been concluded and that he had predetermined matters. My view is that part of the terms of reference cited by Senator Ellison earlier required the committee to look at the circumstances of the Fairfax takeover in 1991 and related matters to see whether there had been any quid pro quo and any arrangement. I say without fear of contradiction that no evidence before the committee to date suggests that in any way, shape or form. I have no doubt that when we come to deliver the final report no evidence in those terms will have been presented to the committee.

This committee has become simply a waste of taxpayers' money. Important questions in respect of foreign investment guidelines ought to be treated seriously. Senator Alston's political intervention with the Age was at best unwise. There is a political conflict of interest when the chairman of a committee looking at the Fairfax organisation rings the editor of a major metropolitan daily and says, `I do not like the political line being pursued by Mark Baker. TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say it and Kohler didn't say it.

PARA.TAB: The terms of reference were flawed. They were conceived in malice. That is the root cause of the problem. Tonight we may be able to sort out some matters. I sincerely hope that we can. TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity for Australia to adhere to the previously agreed Interim Planning Target for stabilisation of CO(2) emission at the 1988 level by the year 2000 and to a 20% reduction below that level by the year 2005.

There is no doubt in anybody's mind that the rapid change in the composition of the global atmosphere is the most important threat ever to the global environment. We now have samples 200,000 years old from ice cores; we know what the composition of the atmosphere has been; and we know that the composition of the global atmosphere is changing faster than at any time in geological history.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, we know that this change in the atmosphere is being brought about by human activities—by the burning of fossil fuels and by various other activities. So this is a human produced change which is more rapid than at any time in geological history. We also know that some 40 per cent of all photosynthetic activity on earth is now being consumed either directly or indirectly by humans. When I raised this question with Senator Schacht several weeks ago, he did not even understand the question. It means that some 30 million other species with which we share this planet have only about 60 per cent of that photosynthetic activity available for all their activities of life.

It is also worth stressing that when we look out from the outer reaches of the solar system, as we have been able to do with the Voyager spacecraft journeys, we find that on all the evidence this is the only place in the whole universe which is capable of supporting life, either our form of life or any other form of life. Yet we are carrying out this enormous experiment on the life support systems of this planet. It is quite true, as we may hear from either the government or the opposition, that we do not know what the consequences of this change will be. There are certainly predictions. The intergovernmental panel on climate change has made estimates in relation to changes in global climate, changes in temperature, changes in rainfall and so forth. One must comment that the changes which have been observed are consistent with those models. We are indeed on track for the sorts of changes that those 200 scientists from over 20 countries on two separate occasions have predicted.

So we are conducting this enormous experiment on the life support systems of the only planet which is capable of supporting life and we really do not know fully what the consequences are. This suggests, in line with the ecologically sustainable development principle of precaution, that we should proceed as slowly as possible to change the atmosphere. In other words, we should slow down our rates of burning of fossil fuel; we should slow down those other activities which are affecting the composition of the atmosphere. We should slow down those activities as much as we possibly can until we know what the consequences are.

The whole reason for raising this debate this afternoon is simply that, on all the indications, the government has accepted, temporarily, a very weak set of recommendations. It has not done anything to implement those recommendations and we fear it is now going to move away even from those very weak recommendations for stabilisation by the year 2000 and a 20 per cent reduction by the year 2005 based on the 1988 figures.

It may be asserted—and has been asserted by the opposition in particular but no less on occasions by the government—that there is some conflict between the economy and the environment. We could easily achieve these targets of stabilisation and a 20 per cent reduction by the year 2005 while benefiting the economy. I stress most strongly that Australia, because of its procrastination, is being left behind. Other countries are instituting energy efficiency; other countries are developing more efficient ways of production. They are reducing their costs by doing that and are stealing a march on Australia. So there is in this instance no conflict between the achievement of these targets and the economic wellbeing of this country either in terms of profitability or in terms of employment—indeed, the two things are consonant. We can achieve those greenhouse targets. We can do better, and we can improve the economy and employment at the same time.

Today's Australian Financial Review reports that a letter has been sent to various ministers—Minister Cook, Minister Collins and Minister Beddall—arguing against taxes on energy. The letter is quoted as saying any reductions would have serious trade and competitive consequences for our industries. Do people know that Japan already produces steel using half the amount of energy that Australia uses? Do they know that Japan produces that efficiency because it has high energy costs? Do they know that Japan is able to out-compete Australia in so many ways because it has achieved that efficiency? There is no conflict whatsoever between the achievement of those sorts of reductions in CO(2) emissions and the achievement of an improved economy and an improved employment situation as well.

I turn now to transport. With great difficulty I convinced the government that it should go down the road of supporting ethanol as an alternative fuel. Fortunately, we have now embarked on that road, and Australia is well on the way to developing some very exciting technology which will make ethanol as cheap as petrol. We will indeed be able to use a renewable fuel, provided that the government is serious about supporting the remaining research in the development of ethanol from cellulose.

We already have the world's best technology in solar hot water; a technology which is present in only 6 per cent of Australia's homes. With the application of solar hot water alone we could very substantially reduce the emission of greenhouse gases from electricity generating stations. But we do not find this federal government consistently and seriously addressing the problem of the recalcitrants—and I use that word deliberately—of the electricity utilities around Australia, which have simply sought to increase their production of electricity rather than use least-cost planning to produce a system which has energy service use at the point of use as its principal objective.

I would suggest very strongly that the federal government use its corporations powers, as it did in the case of Tasmania, to say to the electricity utilities around Australia, `You shall import no more heavy generating equipment into Australia for the next 25 years', to force the utilities to adopt least-cost planning and to provide, through various incentives, ways in which domestic hot water services might be just as competitive as the provision of electric hot water. People do not basically need electricity; they need hot water; they need the services which electricity and other energy forms make available. We can do that with fewer greenhouse gas emissions, with more employment and at lower cost by going down the road of alternative energy and energy efficiency.

The intergovernmental panel on climate change has twice said that we need to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions by 60 to 80 per cent as rapidly as possible. Translated into Australia's terms, that means a 92 per cent reduction on a per capita basis. The government has accepted a very weak figure when it suggests stabilisation by 2000, and a 20 per cent reduction by 2005. I am very concerned that the government is going to move away from those adopted standards. I urge the government to stay with those standards or, if possible, to improve on them. Next Monday, 21 March, the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change will come into force. For the first time Australia, like the other parties to the convention, will be legally required to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, yet the Australian government—against the weight of international, scientific and political opinion—has pulled back from the commitments. I urge the government to stay with those, or even better, standards. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health and Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —In October 1990 the Commonwealth government, along with state, territory and local governments, adopted the national interim planning target and agreed to develop a nationally coordinated response. The interim planning target is sometimes, however, mischaracterised, and unfortunately that has happened today. Senator Coulter has not included it at all, because it should be noted that after the words `the year 2005' in his motion the rest of the sentence continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . subject to Australia not implementing response measures that would have net adverse economic impacts nationally or on Australia's trade competitiveness, in the absence of similar action by major greenhouse producing countries.

They are significant words, and I do not think we can ever in this debate avoid confronting them. The target adopted by Australia has a high degree of synergy with the commitments and principles in the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change. It recognises that there is a range of important greenhouse gases, including carbon dioxide, and it does not limit action to a single gas. It also recognises the importance of a global response in order to effectively counter the challenge posed by increasing greenhouse gas emissions. It also recognises that concerted action must take place within the framework of a sustainable Australian economy and a sustainable Australian trade competitiveness as well as protecting the environment.

PARA.TAB: At the same time as Australia adopted the interim planning target, the international community—recognising that the prospect of global climate change resulting from enhanced greenhouse effects presents some of the most far-reaching problems ever faced—agreed to develop a framework convention on climate change under the auspices of the United Nations. The Rio Earth Summit developed a convention that was open for signature at that landmark conference. Australia, along with 150 other nations, signed the convention and announced that we would work towards its early entry into force. We took the pledge seriously, becoming the ninth nation to lodge an instrument of ratification with the United Nations as far back as December 1992.

At the same time, we were developing Australia's national response, becoming one of the first countries in the world to develop an action plan—the national greenhouse response strategy, which I will refer to later. As Senator Cook said, next Monday is a landmark day because it is the day that the convention comes into force. The necessary 50 ratifications needed to bring the convention into force were achieved in December of last year. I suppose that, in itself, is not of great moment but it is worth noting that among the 50 nations were the US, the European Union, Japan, China and India. They are the nations that are the major greenhouse gas emitters. That event will trigger a series of activities that will culminate in the first conference of the parties, which will occur in Berlin in March 1995.

The issues can be divided into two streams of activity: operational and institutional arrangements that must be put in place to assure the rapid implementation of the convention; and work in preparation for the first review of the adequacy of the emissions commitments in the convention. The review of the adequacy of the convention's commitments was formally discussed for the first time at the February 1994 meeting of the negotiating body. Resulting from those discussions, there is now a widespread acceptance that the convention's existing commitments are inadequate and need to be strengthened. As a result of this widespread agreement, there is now a strong expectation that the first conference of the parties will launch a negotiating process for a protocol that will establish further and more detailed commitments to move the global community towards meeting the objective of the convention.

I would like to state quite clearly that, contrary to what some have been saying, Australian support has not diminished or evaporated on the question of the adoption of targets and timetables that acknowledge the principles embedded in the convention, such as the comprehensive approach and equitable burden sharing. At the last negotiating meeting, the Australian delegation also made this point during the discussions on the review of the adequacy of the convention's commitments. However, we also have to recognise that, without credible action by Australia domestically, we will not have any standing internationally to influence events. We are going to have to make sure that our act is in order.

Consistent with this, the Commonwealth government has been pursuing as a priority the adoption and further development of the national greenhouse response strategy. The Council of Australian Governments endorsed that strategy at its meeting in December 1992. Australia's national greenhouse response strategy contains a comprehensive framework for taking action. The three-pronged goal of that framework is as follows: to contribute towards effective global action to limit greenhouse gas emissions and enhance greenhouse gas sinks; to improve knowledge and understanding of the enhanced greenhouse effect; and to prepare for potential impacts of climate change in Australia. The framework also contains a set of objectives and strategies for key economic sectors and areas of public sector activity and some initial actions to abate greenhouse gas emissions.

I want to point out some of the general principles which underlie all of the response measures. These are specified in the strategy. It is important to understand what they are because they guide and explain Australia's approach to responding to the threat of climate change. Response measures should be effective in furthering the strategy goal and be economically efficient. Perhaps more importantly, from Senator Coulter's point of view, one of the principles is that response measures should be directed towards the interim planning target.

The strategy is a phased plan of action towards limiting greenhouse gas emissions, conserving and enhancing greenhouse gas sinks and preparing for the potential impacts of climate change. It also provides for research and analysis—which I note Senator Coulter referred to—amongst other things, to provide a clearer definition of the range of response options and their associated benefits and costs and to develop appropriate technologies to implement response actions. Certainly, in accordance with some undertakings that I have given to Senator Coulter privately, over the next few days I will be taking up with the department some of the matters that he raised here today.

Finally, the strategy contains mechanisms for continued monitoring of the programs identified and for assessing performance in the actions, as well as arrangements for the periodic review and continuing development of the strategy. That includes the scope to reassess objectives as we go along and to reassess programs in the light of new scientific information in this area, because we are getting new scientific information all the time. Therefore, we will monitor international developments, we will monitor the effectiveness of the response actions and we will make sure as we go along that if we need to change then change we shall.

The first reporting on progress with implementing measures and the further development of the strategy is under way. The first part of the report that was presented to COAG summarised the implementation of measures in the strategy in the first year since it was endorsed. The second part of that report will be presented at the next meeting and it will deal with some further issues.

I did make a comment about the response strategy as endorsed in December 1992. It contains only an initial range of actions to abate greenhouse gas emissions. The important thing to note is that more can be done, more is being done and more will be done. Measures adopted in the first phase include actions focused particularly on the energy and transport sectors and things like energy efficient standards for a range of equipment and goods, provision of the information of energy users and looking at environmentally favourable electricity generation technologies, et cetera.

Further actions have been taken by the Commonwealth since the adoption of the strategy, for example, the funding of development of a national greenhouse inventory; encouragement for alternative fuels with a guaranteed excise-free period and with legislation to be introduced soon on a bounty to support development of an ethanol fuel industry; and a research project by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics into possible measures in the transport sector. Also, the Commonwealth is a major sponsor of a study to define opportunities for biomass derived energy and the development of a strategic plan for those industries.

The available menu of potential actions is greater than that considered for the strategy in 1992. It will also grow with time, for example, with improvements in relevant information, technological developments and economic changes. In addition, the development of measures considered to date for the national greenhouse response strategy has largely been limited to Commonwealth and state-territory government actions. The Commonwealth will canvass with the states some proposal which would draw together a picture of Australia's progress by mid-1994. We will then present that to the public.

As I said at the beginning of the statement, the interim planning target has a high degree of synergy with the convention. I think it may be useful to conclude with the objective of the convention, perhaps one of the most important objectives ever crafted in an international treaty, which illustrates the synergy of which I speak. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to stabilise greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system. Such a level should be achieved within a time frame sufficient to allow ecosystems to adapt naturally to climate change, to ensure that food production is not threatened and to enable economic development to proceed in a sustainable manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sentiments and general thrust of this motion by Senator Coulter are supported by the coalition. The actual wording of the motion requires some closer scrutiny. Most Australians accept that the level of greenhouse gases, in particular carbon dioxide, is increasing and that there is a need to reduce these gases, but there is a debate about whether global warming will occur, and that debate continues. Certainly the balance seems to suggest that it will, but I note an interesting article by Roger Pocklington, Kenneth Drinkwater and Richard Morgan entitled `Scientists sceptical of greenhouse alarms', which does in fact make interesting reading.

PARA.TAB: The evidence for the likelihood of global warming is such that we cannot ignore it. I agree with Senator Coulter that we have to slow down the increasing emission of greenhouse gases. It is interesting to note that the analysis of air from previous centuries captured in the Arctic ice and atmospheric measurements taken since the 1950s confirms the rapid increase of carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere.

Because carbon dioxide captures heat in the atmosphere, it follows that we could expect some increase in global temperatures as carbon dioxide levels increase. Fortunately, the equation is not that simple. If it were, we would be experiencing a much greater rise in temperature than the 0.6 degree centigrade rise that has been measured over the last century.

Scientists have tried to model the effects, but the models have been crude compared with the complexity of the system. Early models predicted temperature rises of four to five degrees and accompanying sea rises, due to thermal expansion, of one to two metres. More recent models, however, have predicted a smaller temperature rise of one to two degrees and a tidal rise of 20 centimetres by the year 2030. Many important questions remain to be answered.

There is a very real fear that, as temperatures are not increasing in concert with the increase in greenhouse gases, a critical point may be reached at which the ability of the world to absorb more carbon dioxide is exceeded and a large and sudden rise in temperature occurs as a consequence. It would be foolish for governments to ignore the possibility of global warming. It is the responsibility of governments to keep an open mind, to monitor scientific evidence and to continually adjust policy on the basis of that evidence. It is also essential that governments continue to monitor costs to business and employment as a result of any action they take on global warming.

It is said that more than half of the carbon dioxide emissions in Australia come from the burning of coal. That is why the electricity industry, with its coal burning power stations, is often in the firing line. By cutting down on the use of electricity and by using it more efficiently, Australia will cut down its emission of carbon dioxide. Australia contributes only two per cent of the global greenhouse gases and, consequently, any reduction in our emissions would have only a minimal effect on the overall problem.

However, Australia's per capita emission of greenhouse gases per annum is 11 tonnes compared with the world average of 2.5 tonnes. We are one of the highest per capita users of energy and emitters of greenhouse gases. Unless we reduce our own emissions, we will not have the right to entreat other nations to reduce or restrict theirs.

As a developed country with high per capita greenhouse emissions, we should take the lead in developing techniques and technologies that can be used by less developed countries to contain their greenhouse emissions as they continue to develop. I think Senator Coulter made the point earlier that there is business and money in developing and selling those strategies and techniques.

In an attempt to address the problem of greenhouse and its effects on climate change, the United Nations developed its convention on climate change. The convention was put to the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, known as the Rio conference, held in Brazil in June 1992. The developing countries which signed the convention agreed to a number of commitments, including the recognition that a return to earlier levels of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2000 was desirable—I emphasise `was desirable'—and their eventual aim of returning to the 1990 levels of emission in due course. The convention was not precise about the level of stabilisation by the year 2000 or about when signatory countries should return to 1990 levels of emission.

In October 1990 the Australian government set an interim planning target for the stabilisation of greenhouse gas emissions at the 1988 level by the year 2000 and a 20 per cent reduction in that level by the year 2005. These targets are more ambitious than the targets that Australia agreed to when it signed the UN Convention on Climate Change two years later. One of the failures of the government in this matter has been its failure to consult with industry. It has consulted widely with environmental groups, but it has not consulted nearly as widely with industry. If it had done that, it would have a better appreciation, a better balance and a better idea of the problems those emissions cause to the environment and also the effect of any solutions on business, industry, jobs and employment.

The government has been a little hypocritical on this matter. While exhorting industry to cut its emissions, the government has failed to develop a comprehensive education program for business or domestic users. Further, its own actions in this regard have been less than impressive.

Earlier last year the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the department given responsibility for increasing energy efficiency, was criticised by the Auditor-General's office. The Auditor-General was critical about the government's implementation of the interim greenhouse response initiatives, and concluded that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy had taken insufficient implementation action, even though there was a degree of urgency intended by the government. In its own program of energy efficiency the department had made almost no progress in a two-year program. It was already one year behind.

Equally, the government has been criticised for not evaluating fully the potential implications of its greenhouse emission targets. There are genuine fears within industry that Australia has set itself too high a target for the reduction of greenhouse emissions. In attempting to meet the target additional costs will be put on industry, which will make it less competitive.

I mention that the Business Council of Australia is concerned that the target is inappropriate, given Australia's dependence on fossil fuels, the increasing population and the importance of energy-intensive industries. It would mean a massive cost and structural disruption to attempt to meet the targets proposed by Senator Coulter.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has estimated that to achieve this target would cost $40 billion and would effectively lead to the demise of Australia's coal industry. In other words, if we go too quickly or are too severe, or do not think these restrictions out carefully enough, we will find ourselves exporting jobs overseas as well.

There is a concern as to how governments might regulate to reduce emissions. Possible mechanisms include the setting of goals for emissions, selling pollution `rights', taxes, regulations, subsidies and education. Industry has made it clear that in improving its environmental outcomes it would rather have goals than regulations. It believes it can often reach a goal more cheaply by innovative techniques than it can by conforming to government regulations.

The current emphasis by the government is on education, but the spectre of an energy tax will not go away, especially as to this government an energy tax has the increased government attraction of more revenue. It behoves the government to deny and to put out of contention that it is likely to do that.

Time does not permit me to do this as fully as I intended, but I mention the excellent Australian research into the uses of solar and wind energy, hydro-electricity, which the Democrats for some reason—particularly up my way—seem to oppose, and ethanol. Those alternative forms of energy are projects that Australia has already done a lot of good research into, and we must continue to promote that research to find cost-effective solutions.

But in considering greenhouse emissions and solutions, we must always keep in balance the need to reduce emissions with the certainty of jobs and Australia's exports. Whilst we have a lot of sympathy with the thrust of the urgency motion—of the desirability—we will not be supporting it because of the actual wording.(Time expired)

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Before calling Senator Chamarette, I note that, with agreement from other senators, Senator Chamarette has reduced her normal time of 10 minutes to five so that her colleague, Senator Margetts, can also speak for five minutes later on in the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been very pleasing to note the comments that have already been made in all the speeches. The only thing I find flabbergasting is that Senator Ian Macdonald, with such a good speech and raising a lot of the issues, is indicating that the opposition is not supporting this motion. Nevertheless, I want to concur with much of what he, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Richardson) and Senator Coulter have said.

PARA.TAB: It is true that on Monday, 21 March the convention on climate change will come into force, having been ratified by 50 countries, as was required in December last year. It is part of agenda 21, the agenda for change that was set up by the Earth Summit in Rio. For that reason, the Greens (WA) welcome the opportunity to support this motion, and to present the urgency of it to the government.

Pleasingly, the minister, Senator Richardson, referred to the measures and support for an increase in the timetable and standards that have been expressed. I hope that that will indicate that this government is prepared to do more than it has hitherto done in relation to the climate change convention, and that it will further review the national greenhouse response strategy that it issued earlier this month.

Senator Richardson used part of his statement to talk about a no regrets measure in there being a qualification on the kinds of changes that the government is prepared to look at within Australia as measures to reduce greenhouse gas. I believe he was referring to the definition of `no regrets measures' in the national greenhouse response strategy as those measures that had net benefits in addition to limiting greenhouse gas emissions. He used it in an unfortunate way which could be construed to exclude emission reduction options which are cost-effective or have no net costs.

We need to bear in mind that there are many examples where the alternative strategies are not being properly looked at. An example is my own home state of Western Australia where the $14 billion project, the North West Shelf, is running at a loss. While the cost of production is running from $16 to $22 per litre of oil or gas equivalent, it is selling at $14 a litre. Therefore, the country is subsidising an industry which is destroying our atmosphere at a colossal rate.

As someone pointed out to me the other day, if we allowed every household in Australia either tax incentives or subsidies for solar heaters, it would be a fraction of the cost and reduce the damage that we are pouring into the atmosphere throughout the world as a result of the oil and gas that we are selling. The business sector in this country does not yet accept the responsibility for the change in the climate that is required so that we can actually see not only an improvement economically, but also a dramatic change to the way in which we reduce our emissions and fulfil our national responsibilities.

The national greenhouse response strategy that Australia has recently published is disappointing and compares poorly with actions taken by other developed countries such as Denmark, Germany and the USA. This information is provided by a recent report produced by an international network of environmental non-government organisations. The concerns of the environment movement about the weaknesses of Australia's strategy are confirmed by inspection of Australia's official report on its implementation of the national greenhouse response strategy just released. Western Australia—again I mention my state—one of our main resource development states and highest greenhouse gas producers per capita, did not even contribute to our national report. All other states and territories and the Commonwealth did. For this reason, the Greens (WA) express their support for the motion that is being considered and urge the government to improve its attempts in this regard. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald in this debate. I do not wish to disappoint Senator Chamarette, but I do not hold the same views that she does. I entered this debate with some apprehension, taking on Senator Coulter in the area of his expertise and lifetime dedication. But I have truly put aside those apprehensions because Senator Coulter really did not speak to concerns of the community on this motion. Rather, he took us into the solar system, the outer reaches of the universe, to tell us there was no life out there at all. I do not know why he thought that was relevant. Perhaps he was thinking of migrating at some stage—if this world should come to an end, then Senator Coulter would jump off.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter delved into a number of alternative lifestyles, which seems to be a favourite topic of his. I think the candle wax alternative to energy is Senator Coulter's favourite and most preferred policy. Senator Coulter has to understand, in pushing for this motion to be accepted—if it were read by those in Australian households, they would not understand it—that there are more concerns than just alternative energy policies. There are jobs and livelihoods on the line. I was very disappointed that, in the 10 minutes available to Senator Coulter, he did not show a great deal more sophistication in his approach to this matter because, as I said, he is the so-called expert in this area; he has spent a lifetime studying it.

On the face of it, although this motion is accepted by the coalition as having some merit, if Senator Coulter and his policies are set loose, they are, in fact, quite dangerous and a threat to the economic well-being of Australia. The motion before the Senate basically deals with a new age concept of the greenhouse effect. Senator Coulter is calling for the enforcement of the 1990 Rio conference agreement, to which Australia was a signatory with 48 other countries. From the Rio conference, the federal government has adopted an interim planning target of stabilising emissions of carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide, based on the 1988 levels, by the year 2000, and reducing these emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2005—an ambitious program.

It is believed that this target would stabilise the greenhouse gas emissions and stem the alleged and, indeed, phoney prophecies of severe climate change and overheating of the earth. This is being pushed as the politically correct line, but is it real? Scientific data and commentary of late that are starting to come in weigh heavily against the perceived dangers of the greenhouse effect—those extreme examples put forward by Senator Coulter and his colleagues. While carbon dioxide levels are going up, it can be said that there is no direct link with current climatic changes. It is not a scientific fact. In fact, Senator Coulter would be hard pressed to find substantial climatic changes anywhere in the world today. All are marginal climatic changes, other than the normal and expected evolutionary changes in climate. This is borne out by the fact that the doomsday predictions of the 1980s have fallen flat in the 1990s. I will refer to two of those predictions of the 1980s.

Scientists at the 1987 greenhouse conference, which was held in Melbourne, warned of higher temperatures, rising sea levels, changing rainfall patterns and more frequent and more violent weather extremes, such as cyclones and storms. It was predicted that about 50,000 square kilometres of coastal land would be flooded if sea levels rose an estimated 140 centimetres beyond the year 2000; the year 2030 was referred to.

It should be noted in relation to these doomsday predictions that even the then minister for science, Barry Jones, who is also an expert in the field, saw fit to make qualifications in 1987 regarding these predictions; none of them even looked like occurring. He saw fit, in his opening remarks, to say that much more research was needed because scientists did not yet know enough to accurately predict the impact of the greenhouse effect. Quite frankly, it is now 1994 and most of those predictions have been debunked.

In 1987, there was the great prediction by a group of CSIRO scientists that climatic changes may mean that by the middle of the next century every year would be a potential Ash Wednesday year of extreme bushfire. The article said, `It is the first time the possibility of such a dramatic increase in bushfire risk has been linked to global warming'. That has also been debunked. That is the last time the bushfire risk will ever be linked to global warming. The green movement is fighting a rearguard action in relation to bushfires. They now have to explain how controlled burning and controlled logging are not a better policy for preventing bushfires.

These obsessions have been debunked in the 1990s. Not one of these doomsday predictions even looks like it could occur. The likes of Senator Coulter and those pushing the Rio convention have on their agenda the introduction of a tax upon energy to meet the Rio convention requirements. Such a tax would have a devastating effect upon the living standards of all Australians as the Australian economy is very dependent upon natural resources. Australia is even more dependent upon natural resources than the other signatories to the Rio convention.

Australia is one of the world's largest exporters of coal, the second largest exporter of aluminium and iron ore and is also a significant producer of steel, oil and gas. Yet the export abilities or wealth of the other signatories to the Rio convention do not have such a dependence on energy resources. For example, let us compare Australia with France. Eighty per cent of France's power generation is nuclear. Australia's nuclear power generation is zero. Obviously, France has less to lose in meeting the Rio guidelines than has Australia, as nuclear generation has zero gas emissions.

Has Senator Coulter considered the following effect: in the search for cheaper and more efficient power, post-carbon tax, Australia would be driven to the nuclear option? Is that an option that Senator Coulter supports? I think not. When the lights go out on our electricity industry—predominantly fuelled by coal—what option does Senator Coulter propose to turn on the lights around Australia? I truly believe that Senator Coulter would prefer the candle wax option.

The coalition's position is not in favour of the nuclear option. This has been clearly stated by the shadow minister. I refer to his press release: `Australia has no foreseeable need to consider using nuclear power plants to generate electricity. Australia has abundant supplies of coal and natural gas, and these will meet the national electricity needs'.

In the short time I have to place some balance upon Senator Coulter's urgency motion I conclude by saying that, further to that, we support the no regrets policy, which Senator Coulter would be familiar with. It is a policy where all efforts will be made to reduce CO2 emissions—we accept that—to a point that does not affect the basic standards of living, competitiveness and trading ability of our country. This was also an attachment to the Rio convention signed by our government, which said, `subject to Australia not implementing response measures that would have net adverse economic impact nationally upon Australia'.

SPEECH.PARA: Energy efficiency is a fundamental driver of performance for energy intensive industries and improvements which can be made in energy savings are continuously sought.

PARA.TAB: We in Australia are basing our policy decisions on the greenhouse problem on a fraudulently lacking report produced by the Industry Commission at the end of the ecologically sustainable development process. TALK.START.PARA: —I present my response to the 42nd report of the Privileges Committee, entitled Possible adverse treatment of a witness before the Corporations and Securities Committee. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask that the document be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: The document read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: PRESIDENT'S RESPONSE TO PARLIAMENTARY COMMITTEE REPORT

INTERJECT.PARA: The 42nd Report of the Committee of Privileges, entitled Possible Adverse Treatment of a Witness before the Corporations and Securities Committee, was tabled in the Senate on 27 May 1993. Included in its findings and recommendations was the following:
That the Senate resolve as follows:

That the Senate is of the opinion that all heads of departments and other agencies, statutory office holders and Senior Executive Service officers should be required, as part of their duties, to undertake study of the principles governing the operation of Parliament, and the accountability of their departments, agencies and authorities to the Houses of Parliament and their committees, with particular reference to the rights and responsibilities of, and protection afforded to, witnesses before parliamentary committees. (paragraph 3.8)
The Senate adopted the recommendation on 21 October 1993 and this response gives details of action taken to implement the recommendation.

Following passage of the Senate resolution, my predecessor, the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, wrote to all Ministers advising them of its passage. Similarly, the Clerk of the Senate wrote to the heads of all departments, and to the Public Service Commission, drawing attention to the terms of the resolution. I understand that the Chairperson of the Committee of Privileges advised all Ministers of the content of the report and also of the 36th Report of that Committee, which raised similar concerns.

The content of the reports was drawn to the attention of all Senior Executive Officers in an article written by the Secretary to the Committee and published in SES News of December 1993, in response to an invitation by the Public Service Commission. The Clerk of the Senate has since spoken at one of the SES management seminars which are conducted by the Public Service Commission. It may be hoped that his participation will be a regular feature of subsequent programs.

The earliest response to the recommendations of the report came from the Australian Securities Commission, which, soon after the tabling of the report, arranged for Senators and senior Senate staff to conduct seminars for the Commission's senior officers. So far, these full-day seminars have been conducted in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane, and the senior officers who attended included a Commissioner of the ASC, and Regional Commissioners from New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. A further seminar is scheduled for Perth at the end of April.

Brisbane was also the venue for a seminar conducted for regional heads of Commonwealth departments and authorities, organised on the initiative of the Queensland Regional Commissioner of the Australian Securities Commission, who is also the convenor of that group.

Senator the Hon. Margaret Reynolds, Chairperson of the Committee of Privileges, participated in both Brisbane seminars. Senator John Coates, another member of the Committee and Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, addressed another regional seminar, in Bowral, New South Wales, for regional heads of departments and agencies and for heads of agencies based in Sydney. Senator Bruce Childs, the longest standing member of the Privileges Committee, spoke at the first ASC seminar, held in Sydney, while Senator Rod Kemp addressed ASC officers in Melbourne.

The Procedure Office has received several approaches from departments in Canberra, and has conducted two seminars for all SES officers of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. A further seminar is to be conducted in April, covering SES representatives of several departments. It would be helpful if central agencies such as the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Public Service Commission were to become more actively involved in implementing the Senate resolution. The Department of the Senate would, of course, be happy to cooperate and in the meantime intends to continue its programs to meet individual departmental demands.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I wish to underline the importance of your response and the very good work that has flowed since the adoption, here in the Senate, of the report of the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges. Mr President, I know that your two-page response has been incorporated in the Hansard record and will be read by a wide number of interested persons, not the least of whom will be senior officers of the Public Service in all departments not only here in Canberra but in the states, in all the regions where Commonwealth officers serve. It would pay not only Commonwealth public servants but, indeed, state public servants—all decision makers who have any dealings with the Commonwealth parliament—to study the recommendations of the Standing Committee of Privileges, particularly the 42nd and, indeed, the 36th reports of the committee.
