PARA.TAB: What is the upshot of this whole matter? It is this: citizens of Australia have rights, including the right to make a submission to the parliament without any personal detriment to themselves as a result of making such a submission. They can appear before a Senate committee in a public hearing and they can write a letter to the parliament. We must safeguard the right of every Australian citizen

SPEECH.PARA: to so act. We must ensure that, if there is any infringement upon citizens because they have taken up such a right, there is redress for that and there is no detriment, no punishment and no loss or suffering as a result.

PARA.TAB: I use the 42nd report of the committee as an example. This has been addressed by the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges. Mr Acting Deputy President Childs, you are the longest serving member of the committee and are very aware of the principles about which I will now speak. Senator Reynolds, who is the current chairman of that committee, is in the chamber. I happen to be the deputy chairman. We also have in the chamber, sitting in the Clerk's chair, the Deputy Clerk, who is the secretary of the committee.

My colleague Senator Ellison, who will speak following my remarks, is a new and rising star, if I might put it that way, on the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges. Every single member of the committee goes about his or her work in a bona fide way and I am proud of each of them. The last time I was able to say that was on the occasion of the retirement of the then chairman, Senator Patricia Giles, and Senator Durack. Both of those former senators are from Western Australia.

I do not wish to divert from the issue. I wish to highlight that we had a serious matter of law reform before the Australian parliament. The Australian Securities Commission made a very deliberate submission and its representatives appeared before the committee asked by the parliament to inquire into that law reform.

One of the middle ranking—some would say junior—lawyers serving in the Australian Securities Commission quite conscientiously, as a citizen, had a contrary view. That lawyer put forward a view which was quite contrary to that of his employer. As a result of that, in part—there were other complicating factors, and these were all addressed in our report—this person was dismissed from his employment. One of the reasons for the dismissal cited by the head of the ASC's Victorian office was that the lawyer had made a submission to the parliamentary inquiry which was directly contrary to the view of his employer.

As soon as it was drawn to the attention of that person, and indeed to the attention of the Australian Securities Commission, the commission immediately saw the seriousness of its mistake; that it had acted—some would say it had acted inadvertently or out of ignorance, but certainly without taking responsible action—to punish that person for exercising his ordinary civil rights as an Australian citizen. That whole matter has now been settled. A finding of contempt for that action was found by the committee and by the Senate, and that matter has been very seriously understood within the Australian Securities Commission.

What is so cheering to me as a senator in the way the President has responded with these two pages of summary of the action that has flowed since October when the Senate adopted that report is a wide-ranging set of activities alerting virtually the Commonwealth Public Service to the law of the land and to the rights of Australian citizens and, in particular, public servants, as individuals, to make submissions to parliament; and for them to be able to exercise that right without any detriment or punishment. This has been highlighted by the President of the Senate in the way he has summarised the circulation of the Senate's resolution on this matter by his predecessor, the Hon. Kerry Sibraa; by the Clerk of the Senate in writing to all Commonwealth departments; and by the chair of the Standing Committee of Privileges.

It would seem this set of correspondence has been well received. The evidence of this is that there has been a request for this to be brought to the attention of all senior executive officers. The secretary of the committee was asked to, and did, write an article about this for SES News of December last year. This is available and was circulated to the most senior officers in the Commonwealth Public Service.

In addition to that, the Australian Securities Commission, in many ways the subject of that report, has taken concrete steps to convene seminars in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane—and, with regard to regional commissioners, in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, the ACT and the Northern Territory, with another one planned for Perth—to clarify for ASC officers what the law of the land is on this matter so that the ASC will never again transgress the rights of an Australian citizen.

There have been responses from other regional heads of Commonwealth departments. For example, there has been a seminar for those people in Brisbane. We have also very happily seen such seminars inviting appropriate and well-informed senators to address conferences and seminars of public servants. Senator Reynolds has done so; Senator Coates, another long serving member of the committee has done so; and you, Mr Acting Deputy President, have done so. Senator Kemp responded to an invitation to speak directly to the Australian Securities Commission officers in Melbourne, which is where the original problem arose. In addition, the Procedure Office of the Senate has responded very positively to requests for seminars for SES officers, the most senior officers of the Public Service.

I highlight the two points of anxiety that the President of the Senate has put before us today. He has said that there has been a positive response to make sure that the law of the land is understood throughout the Commonwealth Public Service. But it would be actually enhanced if we saw some concrete action from, in particular, two pivotal decision areas: the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and the Public Service Commission.I reinforce the way the President of the Senate has highlighted those two groups in the hope that this will come before the head of the Public Service Commission and the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet so that there is a concrete response similar in action—not just in words, not just in assent—to that which has been set out in the other paragraphs of the response of the President of the Senate.

I conclude with the general thought—I hope it is not too self-indulgent—that one of the real safety nets, one of the positive guarantees of civil rights in this country, is the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges in so far as it can guarantee, through its investigations and conclusions and recommendations to the Senate, all of which in some 40-odd reports have been accepted by the Senate, that there is no transgression of the civil rights that come within our purview under the law of Australia.

We have a constant brief to, by occasional reports, recommend to the Senate whether there are ways of improving guarantees of the civil rights of Australians and the right of every Australian to open representation and open access to this parliament. May this be a very valuable element of the parliament that we promote by example to other countries so that we might see mature, guaranteed civil rights of this kind not only in Australia but in other countries. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse Senator Teague's comments on the response to the 42nd report of the Committee of Privileges. I also endorse the measures which have been taken in relation to the report, which dealt with the possible adverse treatment of a witness before the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities and resulted in the President's response now before the Senate. Before looking at those measures in more detail, I will refer to Australia's system of government, which might give the Senate some idea as to why this is such an important matter.

PARA.TAB: Let us look back to the formation of the federation. Australia borrowed several constitutional systems to form its government arrangements, the centrepiece of which was a bicameral legislature for our parliamentary system. The principles shaping it are representative democracy and responsible government. Essential to it is the parliamentary committee system. If we are to be representative of the people of Australia, and if we are to be responsible government, then contained in our actions must be open government and accountability. In any democracy the people must be informed and must make an informed choice when, periodically, they choose who will govern them. Through our parliamentary committees the people of Australia have such representation and power exercised on their behalf.

Recently, we have seen the power of the Senate and its committees questioned, and this has been canvassed at great length in the press. In most parliamentary committees the witnesses are public servants or—at the least—ministers, who in turn are advised by public servants. Without going into detail, I note that in the case of the 42nd report of the privileges committee the Senate endorsed a finding of contempt by that committee relating to two senior public servants who had charged a junior officer of the same organisation with misconduct because he had given evidence to a parliamentary committee. That is at the very root of the matter.

The government has recognised the possible problem in relation to this matter and has issued guidelines for official witnesses appearing before parliamentary committees and related matters. Unfortunately, that does not seem to have filtered through the Public Service. I believe that the measures mentioned in the President's report are therefore essential in briefing members of the Public Service in relation to their role when appearing before Senate committees.

The Deputy Clerk of the Senate, Anne Lynch, touched on this problem in her article entitled `Straw men and bogeymen: Public Service accountability to parliamentary committees'. I was interested to note that the Department of the Senate has been conducting a number of seminars for middle level public servants. Page 1 of the article states:

SPEECH.PARA: At virtually every seminar at which the role of parliamentary committees is discussed terrified participants ask the question: "What if I answer a question in the way my senior officers or my ministers do not like?" The next question is invariably: "What happens if I am browbeaten by Senators seeking information?" Obviously, their perception is that they are between the devil and the deep blue sea, with no protection either from a predatory committee or from a vengeful minister or senior officer.

I believe that that highlights the problem we have had to date in relation to public officials appearing before parliamentary committees. It is most unfortunate that they have such an attitude.No sanction should be visited upon any official conducting his or her duty when appearing before a parliamentary committee, which is, after all, an essential tool in the exercise of democracy in this country.

PARA.TAB: Further in her article, the Deputy Clerk of the Senate summarised succinctly the dilemma facing public servants. Page 4 of the article states:

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the obligation of public servants is two-fold: to provide information and advice to ministers, with accountability for the implementation of policy; and to perform precisely the same function in respect of the parliament. The only constraints on this function are those imposed by the parliament itself, whether through legislation, for example, secrecy provisions specifically binding the parliament, or through self-denying ordinances such as the Senate privilege resolutions, which bind committees in what they may require of public servants, and the government guidelines for official witnesses before parliamentary committees.
That is a neat summary of the situation.

PARA.TAB: When one looks at the article and recent events, one can see that there has been a great deal of vindication of the action that has been taken as outlined in the President's report. The 46th report of the Committee of Privileges deals with false or misleading information given to Estimates Committee E, popularly known as the diesel fuel rebate reference. At page 12 of that report the committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The responsibilities of public servants directly answering questions by members of Senate committees are clear: officers are required to answer fully and honestly all questions which are asked of them, to ensure that Senators are not misled by the provision of incomplete information . . . This duty is limited by the constraints imposed on committees by Senate Privilege Resolution 1(16), which provides that:

An officer of a department of the Commonwealth or of a State shall not be asked to give opinions on matters of policy, and shall be given reasonable opportunity to refer questions asked of the officer to superior officers or to a Minister.

Quite clearly, one can draw a parallel between that situation and the one which is outlined in the 42nd report of the Committee of Privileges. At page 13 of its report the Committee of Privileges said:

The Committee endorses the Minister's action in rebuking the officers and places on record its own serious concern at their conduct, in placing both the Minister and the Estimates Committee in the position of giving and receiving information which would shortly be known to be false.

That is a most serious situation, because parliamentary committees should not act upon information which is either incomplete or false. To that extent, I submit to the Senate that members of the Public Service have a most important duty and a most important role when either appearing before such committees or assisting their ministers who appear before such committees.

PARA.TAB: We have only to look at the process of the estimates committees to see just how important that information is, because it is, after all, what the Senate committees and the public rely on. When Senate committee members convene to hear evidence, they hear it on behalf of the people of Australia, who elected them. They are unable to make informed decisions or draw valid inferences if they are labouring under evidence which is incorrect or incomplete. Therefore, the system of government that I mentioned will quickly fracture and decay if the role of parliamentary committees is not upheld and, in particular, if the duties of public officials before them are not outlined.

More recently, in the inquiry conducted by the Senate Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in the Print Media, we saw a situation where various public servants and former public servants refused to provide information or documentation to that committee. That has achieved a great deal of public interest and publicity. In a recent article Padraic McGuinness argued that this dilemma is much more important than other controversies raging across the country. In a recent article in the Weekend Australian he stated that this goes to the very function of responsible government. Indeed it does.

At this very moment, questions are being asked as to the power of parliamentary committees and the power of the Senate. These are essential questions which need to be answered for the sake of democracy in this country. We will be unable to function much further either efficiently or democratically if we do not answer these questions. In so doing, we would be negligent not to keep our Public Service informed as to its role and duty when it performs its most important function of appearing before such committees.

When I look at the President's response, I am pleased to see that, following the recommendation adopted by the Senate on 21 October last year, a number of actions have been implemented. I noticed the various seminars that have been attended by a number of the senators involved with the privileges committee. I can only applaud such action and congratulate them for their efforts in that regard. After all, we cannot expect much from our Public Service if we do not tell it what is expected of it.

By enumerating guidelines for public officials appearing before such parliamentary committees, we are covering only the first half of the problem. The second half of the problem is to make sure that it is understood and that it will be followed. I firmly believe that, by virtue of the 42nd and 46th reports of the Committee of Privileges, this message will be conveyed clearly to those officials in the Public Service of this country.

I, for my part, would be only too pleased and privileged to participate in any further action in relation to the dissemination and briefing of such information to the members of our Public Service. I can say only that I believe that, whilst we jealously guard the role of parliamentary committees and recognise the most essential tasks that they carry out in providing information to the people of Australia, there is a future to a system of government in this country which I believe is one of the best in the world, and the parliamentary committee system forms part of that. I look forward to future measures taking place, as have taken place, as outlined in the President's response.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the Auditor-General's report No. 29 of 1993-94: Project Audit—Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development—National Industry Extension Service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this is the first report of the Auditor-General since the government announced that it was going to at least consider the Auditor-General being made directly responsible to the parliament in response to an arrangement made with the Australian Democrats. We would be much happier if that arrangement to have the Auditor-General responsible to the parliament rather than to the government was not simply under consideration. We would have hoped there was total commitment to that because, unfortunately, the Auditor-General has been subjected to non-stop attack by this government, not least as a result of the ALP's role as its landlord. The Auditor-General is, quite frankly, being ripped-off in an incredible way by the landlord that it did not know it had—a sort of Clayton's landlord; the landlord you have when you do not know you have one—because there was a front put in so that Auditor-General's was not aware of who its landlord really was. I hope that matter will be resolved fairly soon.

PARA.TAB: There has been a policy of consistent attack on the Auditor-General, a freezing of his funds, and as a consequence the Auditor-General believes he is unable to do the job which he believes should be done by the Australian National Audit Office. We have seen examples of that kind of campaign spreading a little wider. I noticed a press article just a few weeks ago suggesting that the private sector auditors ought to come in and do the audits of governmental instrumentalities. The point being made—curiously enough, I might say—is that the Auditor-General cannot claim the credit for latching onto the sports rorts because all he did was see what I had been doing in Senate estimates committees and as a result he looked into them. It is exactly the opposite.

The fact that the Auditor-General is there gives an added dimension and depth to the benefits that emerge from Senate estimates committees. The government might trample all over us and take no notice of anything we point out, but the Auditor-General is there to ensure that the important matters brought up by opposition senators in Senate estimates committees are properly examined if they merit that kind of examination. I am very grateful for the Auditor-General's devotion to duty in the face of consistent attacks from this government for the fearless way he has done what is no more than his duty.

It would seem to me an extraordinary situation for anyone to suggest that private sector auditors should be brought in to do the Auditor-General's job with government instrumentalities if we recognise one of the problems that emerges in private sector auditing—and I am not being critical of any individual auditors. That problem is that while auditors in the private sector are directly responsible to the shareholders, it is the directors who recommend their appointment. I am not aware of any situation in which members of a company at an annual general meeting have overridden that recommendation.

But if one had this situation in the government the problem would be that an auditor doing a major audit, like a government instrumentality, may be under a great deal of pressure to in fact maintain that job. In other words, if there are pressures brought on him by a government instrumentality that might involve the auditor being pressured to see things in the way of the instrumentality rather than in the way the auditor would rather see them, then obviously the threat of the loss of that audit job would be a major problem for the auditor.

This kind of conflict does not emerge in the private sector because it would be disastrous for a major company if a major auditor was `sacked' because he would not bend to the will of the directors, and no doubt the marketplace would deal with that company appropriately. There is no marketplace for this penalty, or punishment if you like—this oversight—to be available in the public sector, apart from the parliament itself. It would be quite improper for an auditing group that had a vested interest in maintaining that audit to be put in the terrible position by government of being pressured to do what the government wants. We have seen the way the Auditor-General has resisted that sort of pressure from this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I thought Senator Baume was going to make some preliminary remarks and then get onto the subject of the report that he has supposedly moved to take note of, but he has gone for six minutes now without even mentioning the report.

—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: Senator Baume is addressing the report. One of the problems the Auditor-General has in fulfilling his role is the way in which the dreadful Labor government has—
—Senator O'Chee, what is your point of order?

—The point of order is: Senator Baume's comments are entirely relevant for the simple reason that the Labor government has starved the Auditor-General of the necessary funds to carry out his role. In fact, if Senator Coates read this report he would see that the Auditor-General in this case declined to go any further, obviously because he did not have the resources—that is the point that Senator Baume is addressing, and that is the point that is made on the first page.
—There is no point of order. I think Senator Baume has ranged widely on the topic, but I am sure he is about to come to the report itself.

—Yes, I was, in fact, making those comments by way of a preliminary discussion, because, as I pointed out at the beginning of my remarks, this is the first report since the government gave the undertaking that it would at least examine the serious need to have the Auditor-General directly responsible to the parliament rather than to the government itself. There is no doubt, as Senator O'Chee says, however, that this is only a preliminary study of the role and administration of this program because the Auditor-General did not proceed to a full efficiency audit. One of the reasons for his not proceeding with that, of course, is that the mandate of the audit office does not enable it to audit the operations of state government bodies, except in very restrictive circumstances. Nonetheless, the restraints put upon the audit office by lack of funding are a key factor in limiting the many activities the Auditor-General would like to pursue, as the Auditor-General himself has said many times.

PARA.TAB: The National Industry Extension Service, which is the subject of this audit report—a project audit—is a joint Commonwealth-state and territories program which aims to assist firms to become more internationally competitive. The major responsibilities of the Commonwealth are to coordinate and monitor the system—and, I might say, to put in a fair amount of money as well. These functions are carried out by the Department of Industry, Technology and Regional Development. Commonwealth expenditure on the program in 1992-93 was $16 million. While the Commonwealth puts up a lot of the money, the states have primary responsibility for the delivery of the program to clients. The report of the audit office states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian National Audit Office has a preliminary study of the role of DITARD in the administration of the program.
The preliminary study indicated that the department plays a significant part in coordinating the activities of the NIES—
the National Industry Extension Service—
network and has performed its role in an essentially sound manner.

It is very pleasant to see the Auditor-General being able to report that a body has conducted itself in an essentially sound manner. Despite what may be the impression from a lot of publicity, the great bulk of governmental bodies are conducted in an essentially sound manner. But the Auditor-General, ever alert, has found many instances where there have been major problems—such as the sports rorts affair—that have to be brought to the attention of the parliament and given the backing of the objectivity of the Auditor-General.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, even though the program basically gets a clean bill of health, the audit office considers in this case that the extent to which the program is effective in achieving its primary objective of making firms internationally competitive needs to be more clearly established. There is no doubt that there is a bipartisan approach within this parliament about the need for Australia to be more internationally competitive and for firms to be assisted, where appropriate, in achieving that kind of objective. The Auditor-General states:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, it is considered that a greater priority should be given to tracking the progress of firms that have participated in the program.

It is just like the sports rorts affairs. We discovered in a Senate estimates committee the other day that there had been no really effective study of the effectiveness of that program. Once again, we see that there is a need to track the progress of firms that have participated in the program. We were told at the Senate estimates committee which dealt with sport rorts that successful applicants had not been tracked to see what had happened; in fact, it had not even been established whether the applications that were successful were better than the applications that were not successful.

PARA.TAB: I think the Auditor-General is quite right adopting the same sort of approach here. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The appropriateness of using subsidised consultancies as the means of assisting the majority of clients should also be reviewed.
I will deal with that in a minute. The report continues:

It was found that the NIES Branch of DITARD had not gained assurance that all of the States applied procedures in administering subsidies that minimise the risk of fraud and protect the integrity of their respective subsidy approval and payment systems. A review of their procedures has been recommended.

That is a proper recommendation. One of the problems is that taxpayers' money from the federal stream is disbursed by the states. So, obviously, there has to be proper supervision to ensure that the risk of fraud does not become too great. Going into a little detail, the Auditor-General's report says:

PARA.TAB: The States have primary responsibility for the delivery of NIES services to firms. However, the Commonwealth provides some funding to each State and . . . some direction on how the funds are used. The practice of using the major proportion of NIES funds to subsidise consultancies as a means of delivering extension services appears to have evolved, rather than to have been specifically and formally decided at the national level. It is acknowledged that NIES provides some services such as networking and quality assurance which assist firms other than through individual subsidised consultancies, but these remain in the minority.

Rigorous consideration of the effectiveness or otherwise of the program should entail review of the appropriateness of current delivery methods and the feasibility of any alternatives that may have wide application. It would be appropriate for the department to encourage a regular review. In particular, it should promote examination of whether subsidised consultancies for the majority of clients is cost effective and the most appropriate means of meeting the objectives of the program.

It may also be appropriate to examine the relative merits and cost effectiveness of the various subsidy structures used by the states in the light of how effective existing practices are found to have been. Issues such as whether the level of subsidy should reduce as the firm engages in more NIES services could also be given further consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General notes that the issue of what constitutes adequate evidence that firms have paid a consultant's fee in full before claiming payment of a subsidy should also be included for review. That seems to be a vital requirement and it is a matter of some concern that the Auditor-General is apparently not satisfied on that level. The audit office understands that there is no present indication that manipulation of payments is occurring but considers that investigating the practicality of a procedure which could provide better control would be prudent.

PARA.TAB: Finally—this is a matter that is certainly close to my heart—the Auditor-General looks into the matter of assistance to small firms. This program is not simply aimed at people with big export potential but aimed at small firms where I believe there is an incredible future for large export earnings to develop if given the right and enthusiastic support by government and others in this area. In the course of the preliminary study, the view was put to the audit office that subsidised consultancies may not be the best way that the program can assist small firms.

The concern was that some small firms may be encouraged to undertake relatively expensive consultancies which may produce a weighty report that addresses longer term issues beyond the firm's most pressing needs for survival in the short to medium term. It was felt that the executives of such firms might find a report and its recommendations overwhelming, put it aside and direct their attention back to shorter term needs. In other words, the whole point of the program could well be missed.

The Auditor-General says it was suggested that some such firms would derive greater benefit if a form of mentoring was provided with expertise being made available on a periodic basis, such as monthly, to give practical assistance in overcoming problems and impediments to international competitiveness. The audit office understands that NIES does provide assistance through methods other than individual subsidised consultancies and that small firms are encouraged to participate in activities such as networking and group quality assurance programs. The department advised, however, that it was sensitive to the needs of smaller firms, pointing out that several NIES products had been modified for

SPEECH.PARA: easier, less costly use by smaller clients and that a number of self-help manuals for small enterprises had been developed. Commonwealth NIES also advised that, following the recent restructure of the department, it was now part of the broader business improvement programs branch, which seeks to address development of firms of all sizes.

PARA.TAB: I say in conclusion that I hope small businesses that are keen on developing export markets will in fact be looking into this program. There is a fair amount of Commonwealth money in it. Maybe it is not enough in some people's view, but there was something like $16 million in 1992-93. I commend the Auditor-General for his report on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 24 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it the practice of the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) to review international literature on the toxicological properties of agricultural chemicals rather than performing its own research.
(2) Which publications were reviewed as part of the NHMRC decision to set a level of 20 ug/L for the pesticide atrazine.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The NHMRC considers information from a wide range of sources when assessing the toxicological properties of a chemical. This information may include reports published in scientific journals and monographs, information from national or overseas government agencies, reports published by some international organisations and information provided by chemical companies.

(2) No level for atrazine has been formally set. It is presumed that the honourable senator is referring to the health value for atrazine in drinking water referred to in the draft Australian Drinking Water Guidelines. These are draft guidelines, which still require endorsement from the Agricultural and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand before further consideration by the NHMRC.
